CNIL considered that the data recorded by an automatic vehicle license plate recognition system (the car plates, the speed and the time in which the car drove through a point) was personal data, and thus the automatic system would need to comply with the GDPR, with implications for data retention and cybersecurity.
excerpt: "The CNIL recalls that the truncated license plate numbers constitute personal data, since they are coupled, as in this case, to a timestamp and the location of the section radar and are likely to be cross-referenced with other data, including pictures concerning the vehicle and its passengers. Also, the retention period of twenty-four hours applies both to complete license plate numbers and to truncated license plate numbers of the second and penultimate characters, the amended Order of October 13, 2004 not providing for a distinction on this point.”

summary: In 2021, CNIL opened an investigation regarding the data processing carried out by ClearView AI, and ordered the company to cease data processing from French data subjects, as it did not present an adequate legal basis. It also noted ClearView prevented users from exercise their rights of access and deletion. The deletion of data previously collected was also ordered. In 2022, the investigation was closed and an administrative fine of 20 million euros was issued. In a follow-up 2023 decision, as the company did not provide any proof of compliance, a penalty of 5.2 million euros was imposed (Délibération de la formation restreinte n° SAN-2023-005 du 17 avril 2023 concernant la société X).
excerpt:
"
(…) As part of the investigations conducted by the CNIL, the company was asked about the legal basis of this processing, within the meaning of Article 6 of the GDPR. The company did not provide any answer on this point. The company's confidentiality policy, previously mentioned, also does not mention the legal basis of said treatment.
It can be noted from the outset that the company has not obtained the consent of the data subjects to the processing of their personal data.
(…) With regard to the legal basis relating to the legitimate interests pursued by the data controller, provided for in Article 6. 1. (f) of the Regulation, it should be recalled as a preliminary point of thumb that the 'publicly accessible' nature of a data does not affect the qualification of personal data and that there is no general authorization for the reuse and re-processing of publicly available personal data, in particular without the knowledge of the data subjects. (…) In the present case, even if the interest of the company were based on the economic interest which it derives from the operation of the database in question, that interest should nevertheless be balanced with the interests or the fundamental freedoms and rights of the data subjects, taking into account the reasonable expectations of the persons based on their relationship with the controller, in accordance with Article 6.1(f) of the GDPR, read in the light of recital 47 and the ECDPS opinion on the concept of legitimate interest referred to above.
In this case, the processing is particularly intrusive: it collects a large number of photographic data on a given person, which are associated with other personal data that may reveal various aspects of privacy. From this data, a biometric template is constituted, i.e. biometric data allowing, if it is reliable, to identify the person in a unique way from a photograph of the person: the possession of such data by a third party constitutes a strong invasion of privacy. Finally, it should be noted that this treatment concerns an extremely high number of people.
In addition, it is necessary to determine whether the data subjects could reasonably expect, at the time and in the context of the collection of personal data, that they will be subject to such processing by company X. In this respect, there is no relationship between the company and the persons concerned. While they can reasonably expect third parties to have occasional access to the photographs in question, the publicly accessible nature of the photographs in question is not sufficient to consider that the persons concerned can reasonably expect their images to feed into facial recognition software. Finally, the software operated by the company is not public and the vast majority of the people concerned are unaware of its existence.
“

summary: CNIL imposed a 32 million euros fine to Amazon France Logistique due to several data protection violations associated with its warehouses workers’ monitoring. Data about each employee’s activity was continuously collected and was stored for over a month so periodic performance reports could be created. Consent was deemed inapplicable due to employer-employees imbalance, and thus the processing would have to be based on legitimate interests balancing, which was not met in some of the monitoring practices.
excerpt:
"71. However, the company's interest in ensuring safety and quality in its logistics centres must be balanced against the interests or fundamental freedoms and rights of the data subjects, taking into account their reasonable expectations, based on their relationship with the controller, in accordance with Article 6.1.f) of the GDPR, read in the light of recital 47 and the aforementioned opinion on the concept of legitimate interest.

72. In this case, the restricted training notes that the collection of the Stow Machine Gun indicator amounts in practice to following the speed of succession of the employee's actions, in each of the gestures he performs on a direct task, by associating an error indicator each time this speed is less than 1.25 seconds. However, the restricted training notes that this information reveals a behavior of the employee in the way he performs his direct tasks and is likely to exercise on him a continuous monitoring of the delays associated with each of his actions on direct tasks, with a measure of the order of the second. It therefore considers that this indicator has a significant intrusive character and that its treatment is likely to have negative moral repercussions on the employee, which may result from this continuous monitoring that it allows of his activity on direct tasks. The restricted training also notes that the processing of this indicator concerns a large number of people, since it targets all employees working in its warehouses.

73. Moreover, the restricted training considers that monitoring of such precision exceeds the reasonable expectations of employees who, while they can expect, as employees of the company, that their work will be subject to some monitoring, cannot reasonably expect that their actions carried out with the scanners to be monitored to the nearest second.

74. Thus, the restricted training considers that the treatment of this indicator exceeds what is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests of the company to ensure the quality and safety in its logistics centers, since it excessively infringes the rights and interests of employees working in warehouses - in particular those to the protection of their private and personal life, as well as their right to working conditions that respect their health and safety.

75. Consequently, the restricted training considers that the treatment of the Stow Machine Gun indicator linked to the identity of the employee is not based on any legal basis, in violation of Article 6 of the GDPR.

“

caseName: Délibération n° 2023-068 du 15 juin 2023 portant avis sur un projet de décret relatif aux modalités de mise en œuvre des traitements algorithmiques sur les images collectées au moyen de systèmes de vidéoprotection et de caméras installées sur des aéronefs, pris en application de l'article 10 de la loi n° 2023-380 du 19 mai 2023 relative aux jeux Olympiques et Paralympiques de 2024 et portant diverses autres dispositions
summary: CNIL issued a favourable decision regarding a draft decree of the French Ministry of Interior, which aimed to develop an algorithmic system to process video surveillance during the 2024 Olympic and Paralympic Games. A Data Protection Impact Assessment was carried out, pre-determining the events to be detected by the system, the provision of human intervention, etc.

caseName: Injunction order against Deliveroo Italy s.r.l
summary: The Italian Data Protection Authority fined Deliveroo Italy €2.6 million for GDPR violations, particularly concerning its use of automated rider booking systems, as the company failed to provide meaningful information about how these algorithms operated, the logic behind them, or their impact on riders’ opportunities, nor did it provide for human intervention or ensure the system was accurate.
excerpt: "In the present case, the application of Article 22 of the Regulation must be considered in the light of the provisions of paragraph 2, letter a) which excludes the application of the right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, which produces legal effects or which significantly affects the data subject when it turns out that the processing is necessary for the execution of a contract stipulated between the parties. In this case, however, Article 22(3) of the Regulation provides that the controller implements appropriate measures to “precute the rights, freedoms and legitimate interests of the data subject, at least the right to obtain human intervention [...], to express their opinion and to challenge the decision”. On the basis of the investigations carried out, it does not appear that the company has taken such measures. Furthermore, it does not appear that the company, in relation to the processing carried out as the data controller, has adopted technical and organizational measures to protect the interested parties aimed at periodically verifying the correctness and accuracy of the results of the algorithmic systems, the accuracy, relevance and adequacy of the data used by the system with respect to the purposes pursued, and to reduce as much as much as possible the risk of distorted or discriminatory effects, with reference to the operation of the digital platform (see specific references in recital 71, cit.; v. European Commission, A Union of Equality: The Strategy for Gender Equality 2020-2025, 5.3.2020, COM(2020) 152 final, "Arth algorithms and related machine learning, if not sufficiently transparent and robust, are likely to reproduce, amplify or contribute to gender bias that programmers may not be aware of or which are the result of a specific data selection"). This also in relation to the obligations imposed by the sector discipline regarding the operation of the platforms (see art. 47-quinquies, Legislative Decree no. 81/2015, in force since 3.11.2019, according to which "1. The anti-discrimination rules and those to protect the freedom and dignity of the worker provided for employees, including access to the platform, apply to workers referred to in Article 47-bis. 2. Exclusion from the platform and reductions in work opportunities attributable to non-acceptance of the service are prohibited", on which, more extensively, par. 3.3.9.; v. also Consultative Committee of the Convention for the Protection of Individuals with regard to automatic processing of personal data (Convention 108), Guidelines on Artificial Intelligence and Data Protection, Strasbourg, 25 January 2019, “AI developers, manufacturers, and service providers should adopt forms of algorithm vigilance that promote the accountability of all relevant stakeholders throughout the entire life cycle of these applications, to ensure compliance with data protection and human rights law and principles”. Finally, with regard to the feedback mechanism, it does not appear that the company has taken appropriate measures to avoid improper or discriminatory use of reputational mechanisms based on feedback. (…)”

summary: Garante Privacy issued a limitation order on the ReplikaAI application, as it failed to provide information about data processing, especially of children, which hinders the possibility of ascertaining in which legal basis did it rely on, breaching the GDPR.
The Italian DPA fined a company which used a software that automatically generated e-mail addresses to send unsolicited marketing communications. The fine was of 5 thousand euros.
excerpt:
"Therefore, the processing of personal data for marketing purposes, carried out with the use of personal data lists found on the Internet or randomly generated, turned out to be devoid of the requirements of legality, fairness and transparency identified by art. 5 of the Regulation.
In addition, the described conduct gave rise to the sending of promotional messages without consent, pursuant to articles 6, par. 1, letter a) of the Regulation and 130, paragraphs 1 and 2, of the Code, since Mitja himself has stated that he had never acquired prior consent.
“

summary: The case regarded the ShareArt project, implemented in the Palazzo D`Accursio in Bologna, which used a facial detection system, based on a convolutional neural network, to detect faces looking at artworks and collect information about the associated behavior. Garante Privacy held that the system involved processing of personal data, but lacked a legal basis.
excerpt:
"In summary, a frame in facial detection systems refers to a single digital image captured by a camera or video source that contains one or more human faces. The processing of each frame is essential to detect and recognize the faces present and can require several processing operations, such as image segmentation, applying a classifier and extracting facial features.
In light of what is represented, one can only consider that face detection algorithms require the processing of personal data, consisting of images of people's faces.
It is, in fact, undeniable that the starting data used by the algorithm is the image of the face of the person concerned, in front of the work of art. This data, present in the frames captured and subsequently processed, in the opinion of Aeneas, resides for about 100 milliseconds in the RAM of the SBC electronic card, to then be overwritten by the next frame. This operation involves the processing of personal data, albeit for a very short time, necessary for the identification, by CNN, of faces and for the extraction of other relevant information.
Although, therefore, the described system does not provide for a treatment of the images of the visitors' faces, aimed at biometric recognition and identification, it is undeniable that the operation of the system is based on an initial acquisition of images containing the visitors' faces, subsequently processed precisely in order to identify, within them, the faces. The frames reside on the system for a very short period, but still sufficient to implement a processing of personal data by the subjects involved (see provisionally December 21, 2017, n. 551, web doc. n. 7496252, relating to a substantially similar case, in which "albeit for a short period of time, equal to a few tenths of a second, the system installed [by the data controller] involves [va] a processing of personal data, consisting of the images of the face of the interested parties, aimed at deduce from the image of the face a series of information used to carry out analysis of the advertising audience”).”

summary: A company sought a prior consultation for the conduction of a retrospective health study aimed at applying AI to predict prognosis for cancer patients given their condition and different chemotherapy treatments. Garante Privacy issued a favourable opinion, noting the legal basis for the processing was accurately identified, that is, processing special categories of personal data that is necessary for the "public interest in the area of public health”. It remarked the importance of transparency and of ensuring the anonymization techniques used to share the data (in scientific publications, etc.) are effective across time.
excerpt: "Furthermore, as part of the periodic checks that the data controller is in any case required to carry out also in reference to the persistence of the effectiveness of data anonymization measures and technological evolution, it is considered necessary that the Company also undertakes to remove any singularity, if, by any means, becomes aware of it at a stage subsequent to the application of the aforementioned anonymization techniques, and to keep track of these events, and to repeat in this circumstance the assessment of the risk of re-identification in the light of the causes that have determined the occurrence of this singularity (see on the point, the Opinion of June 30, 2022, doc. Web 9791886 and of March 7, 2023, doc. web n. 9875254).”

summary: Garante Privacy fined a company on 70 thousand euros for using facial recognition systems for monitoring workers’ attendance, although this is possibility is not required in Italian law, and there were less invasive alternatives, such as badges, etc.
excerpt:
"Given, in this regard, that the Company did not illustrate (nor documented in the course of the proceedings) which "ordinary contrast instruments" had been concretely adopted and had turned out to be "completely ineffective", in order to be able to account for the actual working hours provided and to ascertain the presence of workers in the workplace, measures could have been adopted useful for the purpose but less invasive for the rights of the interested parties (e.g. automatic checks by means of badges, direct verifications, etc.).
The assessment of proportionality of the processing of biometric data consisting of facial recognition should also have taken into account the risks to the rights and freedoms of the interested parties related to the use of this particular biometric technology as recognized both by the national law and at the European level (see d.l. 10/5/2023, n. 51, conv. in l. 3/7/2023, n. 87, which with art. 8-ter extended to 31 December 2025 the suspension of the installation and use of video surveillance systems with facial recognition systems "in public places or open to the public, by public authorities or private subjects", this at In order to "discipline in accordance with the eligibility requirements, conditions and guarantees relating to the use of facial recognition systems in compliance with the principle of proportionality provided for in Article 52 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union"; see also: European Data Protection Board, Guidelines 05/2022 on the use of facial recognition technology in the area of law enforcement, adopted on 26/7/2023, spec. points 17, 34 and 35 on the risks of facial recognition; Guidelines 3/2019 on the processing of personal data through video devices, adopted on January 29, 2020, spec. points 4 and 73; see also the Provv. of 10 February 2022, n. 50, web doc. n. 9751362, adopted, albeit in a different context, regarding facial recognition).
“

summary: Upon an agreement between GEDI Gruppo Editoriale S.p.A and OpenAI to license content for training systems and providing users with Italian news, Garante Privacy started an ex officio procedure and issued a warning for possible violations of several articles of the GDPR. It considered the legitimate interests test of the Data Protection Impact Assessment failed to consider the large scale and the particular nature of the treatment, that individuals contained in the articles did not reasonably expect the articles to be communicated with OpenAI.
excerpt:
"CONSIDERING that it is not sufficiently clear how the legal basis of the legitimate interest used by GEDI, in the terms described above, for the processing of data for journalistic purposes, may also be a suitable legal basis to allow GEDI to communicate the personal data included in the editorial contents to OpenAI, also for "training" operations of its artificial intelligence applications; the latter activity, as reported by GEDI itself, "fully removed from the participation and control of GEDI and the GEDI Group's head companies";
CONSIDERING that the individuals whose personal data, common and particular, contained in the archives and articles that will be communicated to OpenAI, cannot reasonably expect such a communication and that the supplementary paragraph of the privacy policies published on the websites of the headlines involved, produced by GEDI, does not appear sufficient to consider fulfilled the obligation of transparency referred to in articles 13 and 14 of the Regulation, given that as of today this paragraph is not yet published (e.g. the privacy policy of La Repubblica is updated to December 2023) and that the same is aimed at users registered at the aforementioned tested and not to the interested parties whose data are communicated to OpenAI;”

summary: Upon a security breach that occurred in 2023 and exposed data from ChatGPT users, Garante noted it had not been adequately notified. It also noted the legal basis for training the GPT models was not adequately identified. It fined OpenAI in 15 million euros and ordered the company to carry out an institutional communication campaign, lasting for six months, to promote public awareness regarding the operation of the ChatGPT service and its implications to personal data. The contents of the communication had to be approved by the Guarantor.

The company (Via Quatro) which manages metro lines of São Paulo’s public transportation was sued by a consumer association organization for collecting images of users’ for marketing and commercial purposes, particularly, to detect the characteristics of consumers in different places and at different times. The fact that the data processing occurred without consent and without notice was considered unlawful, violating data privacy rights, and causing collective damages, because it was not possible to ascertain how many people used the services each day and were affected. The company appealed, but the Appellate Court upheld the decision and increased the fine to 500 thousand reais. The case is pending on appeal to the Superior Court.
excerpt: "It is undisputed that the capture of the images, now discussed, was used for advertising and commercial purposes, given that the aim was to detect the main characteristics of individuals who were circulating in certain places and times, as well as emotions and reactions presented to the advertising broadcast on the equipment. Furthermore, it is an undisputed fact that users were not warned or notified beforehand or later about the use or capture of their image, which clearly violates the right to clear and adequate information about products and services, as well as protection against misleading and abusive advertising, coercive or unfair commercial methods. The defendant, as a public service concessionaire, is responsible for bearing the risk of the economic activities it carries out, especially since they involve the fundamental rights to intimacy, privacy, image and honor of consumer users, which did not occur, since the images of users collected during the provision of the public service were used for commercial purposes.”

summary: The ruling notes that existing jurisprudential tools like damage valuation scales lack individualized justification, and while AI might eventually assist in grouping similar cases and promoting consistency, this role remains aspirational. For now, human judges must construct and justify damage awards based on the specific evidence and context of each case.
excerpt: "Probablemente, en tiempos cercanos, el desarrollo de la inteligencia artificial otorgará mayores herramientas para la búsqueda, selección y agrupación de casos semejantes, a fin que se otorguen respuestas semejantes, limitando con ello la arbitrariedad. Por ahora, esa delicada y penosa tarea está radicada en las personas, primero, las que al construir su pretensión deberán esforzarse en demostrarla, y luego en la ingrata tarea que asumen los jueces y juezas en justificar con el mérito de esa prueba el valor que ha de concederse. En este caso, acudimos a nuestro propio y personal baremo el que hemos construido bajo las reglas de la adopción de los acuerdos, y nuestra propia experiencia como adjudicadores en otros casos, algunos lamentablemente originados en circunstancias aún más trágicas.”

summary: The court ruled that the requested institutional emails must be disclosed, overturning a prior decision by the Council for Transparency. It found that these communications, despite being emails, were generated within the exercise of public duties and thus constitute public information, not private correspondence. Furthermore, the court noted that the government could use tools, including artificial intelligence, to efficiently filter relevant content without invading personal privacy, making secrecy unjustified.
excerpt: "Que en atención a lo antes señalado, se concuerda con el reclamante en orden a que la entrega de la información requerida, que es pública, no implica una afectación a la vida privada de los titulares de los mismos, desde que el riesgo invocado como excepción a la publicidad de los actos de la administración, debe ser evidente, sin que en este caso se advierta la exposición que refiere la reclamada, más aún en la actualidad, en que existen diversas herramientas de filtro de correo electrónico, incluso de inteligencia artificial, que son de fácil acceso y uso, lo que permiten seleccionar en forma expedita la información requerida, sin que sea necesario que un tercero revise uno a uno los correos de los funcionarios respecto de quienes se les solicita, obteniendo de este modo indebidamente información contenida en mensajes de carácter personal, que pudieren haber enviado desde la plataforma de correo institucional.”

summary:
The court rejected a protection action against a school that reported a student for using AI (ClotheOff) to generate explicit images of classmates.
It found the school’s report was not arbitrary, as it fulfilled a legal duty to inform the authorities of potentially criminal conduct involving students. The court emphasized that the responsibility for evaluating the legal classification of AI-generated images lies with the Public Prosecutor, not the reporting institution.

The Chilean Court of Appeals rejected a action against Worldcoin over its use of iris scans to generate a digital identity in exchange for cryptocurrency. The court found that the biometric data collection was consented to by the claimant, who voluntarily used the app and received compensation, meaning there was no illegal or arbitrary act. Additionally, it ruled that concerns over data permanence and blockchain storage lacked sufficient evidence and should be addressed through the appropriate data protection procedures, not a constitutional protection action.

A Chilean court upheld a criminal conviction where the defense argued that WhatsApp messages supporting a lawful motorcycle purchase were unfairly dismissed due to concerns about their authenticity, potentially involving AI. The tribunal reasoned that in light of modern technologies like AI that can generate fake messages and images, the defense’s digital evidence lacked proper verification (e.g. source, metadata, and ownership), making it unreliable.
excerpt: "En efecto, dadas las nuevas plataformas que utilizan inteligencia artificial y las innumerables métodos de creación de archivos, documentos, fotografías, etc resultaba de especial relevancia contar con antecedentes que dieran cuenta que efectivamente esa evidencia fue obtenida desde el celular del acusado, en la fecha que allí se indica, y quienes eran las personas titulares de los números de los teléfonos celulares o cuentas de Facebook, para así conocer datos del presunto interlocutor y oferente de la motocicleta.”

summary: A Chilean woman used an AI-powered WhatsApp chatbot from Isapre Cruz Blanca to confirm her unexplained health insurance cancellation, which she later challenged through a constitutional action. The court noted that while the AI chatbot confirmed her cancellation and did not justify it, it did not constitute a formal or arbitrary omission; the termination was based on alleged misuse of benefits, as the company clarified. Since the dispute involved underlying contractual and evidentiary issues, the court held that a protection action was procedurally inadequate and required a full declarative proceeding instead.

The Chilean appeals court ruled in favor of The Not Company (NotCo), affirming that its AI-developed product “Not Milk” did not constitute unfair competition. The court emphasized that NotCo’s use of artificial intelligence to create a plant-based milk alternative is a legitimate form of innovation responding to evolving consumer preferences, not an illegitimate competitive tactic. It also noted that consumers are unlikely to be confused, precisely because the product transparently presents itself as AI-designed, plant-based, and distinct from dairy.
excerpt: "Los antecedentes acompañados por las partes que dan cuenta de la campaña publicitaria desarrollada por la demandada, en caso alguno pretende decir que su producto “es leche”, aunque destaca particularidades de este que son similares a la leche de vaca. Se advierte un importante esfuerzo por informar acerca del origen de la compañía y sus productos diferenciándose de aquellos de origen animal, por ello no es dable presumir que los consumidores regulares de leche de vaca, que prefieren un producto natural, opten por una bebida de origen vegetal, creada a través de la inteligencia artificial, como Not Milk.”

summary: The court ruled that the requested institutional emails must be disclosed, overturning a prior decision by the Council for Transparency. It found that these communications, despite being emails, were generated within the exercise of public duties and thus constitute public information, not private correspondence. Furthermore, the court noted that the government could use tools, including artificial intelligence, to efficiently filter relevant content without invading personal privacy, making secrecy unjustified.
excerpt: "Que en atención a lo antes señalado, se concuerda con el reclamante en orden a que la entrega de la información requerida, que es pública, no implica una afectación a la vida privada de los titulares de los mismos, desde que el riesgo invocado como excepción a la publicidad de los actos de la administración, debe ser evidente, sin que en este caso, se advierta la exposición que refiere la reclamada, más aun si hoy por hoy la inteligencia artificial posibilita el filtro de la información requerida por el reclamante (…)”

summary: The court ruled that the requested institutional emails must be disclosed, overturning a prior decision by the Council for Transparency. It found that these communications, despite being emails, were generated within the exercise of public duties and thus constitute public information, not private correspondence. Furthermore, the court noted that the government could use tools, including artificial intelligence, to efficiently filter relevant content without invading personal privacy, making secrecy unjustified.
excerpt: "Que en atención a lo antes señalado, se concuerda con el reclamante en orden a que la entrega de la información requerida, que es pública, no implica una afectación a la vida privada de los titulares de los mismos, desde que el riesgo invocado como excepción a la publicidad de los actos de la administración, debe ser evidente, sin que en este caso, se advierta la exposición que refiere la reclamada, más aun si hoy por hoy la inteligencia artificial posibilita el filtro de la información requerida por el reclamante (…)”

summary: The court rejected the insured’s claim for coverage and moral damages after a disputed vehicle theft, with the insurer using artificial intelligence to flag inconsistencies in the claim.
excerpt:
"Para que diga a qué se
refiere con algún caso de anomalía en el denuncio realizado por el
asegurado, señaló que ellos como área analizan todos los siniestros que se
denuncian en la compañía, esas denuncias por la experiencia del equipo y
además trabajan con inteligencia artificial que determinan qué tipos de
siniestros pueden tener una característica anómala. Eso se refiere por
ejemplo si el siniestro se produce en la madrugada, si es un siniestro por
robo con hallazgo inmediato, a ellos les levanta ciertas alertas internas que
finalmente los hace tomar la decisión de mandar el caso a investigar. Para
que diga quién hizo el peritaje que refiere y cuáles fueron las conclusiones
de este si las conoce, respondió que el perito asignado en este caso fue
Claudio Salazar. Principalmente existieron inconsistencias entre el lugar que
se indicó como sustracción del vehículo, inconsistencias en los minutos
previos que se encontraba el supuesto conductor del vehículo, en el peritaje
técnico no se encontró manipulación en chapas de contacto y de acceso,
tampoco existían roturas de vidrio, eso principalmente. “

court: 2º Juzgado de Letras del Trabajo de Santiago
summary:
The court upheld the dismissal of a worker after a company automated its subtitling services with AI technology, leading to mass layoffs. The company justified the dismissal by demonstrating that the adoption of an AI-based Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) system was necessary after major clients migrated to AI providers, significantly reducing their workload and revenues.
The court found that the employer proved objective, permanent, and grave technological and economic changes that warranted the termination, consistent with Chilean labor law requirements for dismissals based on company needs.
excerpt: "En razón de lo anterior, Esteno debió ajustar su tecnología y modernizarla a efectos de poder competir efectivamente con las empresas que desarrollan este tipo de servicios, generando y creando un aplicativo igualmente basado en Inteligencia Artificial que realice la labor de subtitulado en tiempo real de la programación a cargo de Esteno. (…) Así pues, la causal de necesidades de la Empresa se encuentra totalmente justificada, toda vez que la medida adoptada por la Empresa corresponde a una imperiosa necesidad de modernizar la prestación de sus servicios, en atención a hechos graves, como fue la pérdida de decenas de clientes en un corto lapso de tiempo, lo que implicó dejar de percibir 58.644 dólares norteamericanos mensuales y un 28% de disminución en la producción de la Empresa, objetivos, pues el origen de esta necesidad no es imputable a la Empresa únicamente y permanentes pues, no se advierte posibilidad de volver a requerir del mismo número de trabajadores para desarrollar una labor hoy en día automatizada. Por lo expuesto, es que la causal de necesidades de la Empresa se encuentra totalmente justificada.”

summary: The case concerns a constitutional challenge in Indonesia arguing that the absence of restrictions on the use of digitally or AI-manipulated images in election campaigns violates the principles of free, fair, and honest elections. The petitioner claims that excessive use of digital and AI technologies to manipulate the image of electoral candidates misleads voters, impeding their constitutional right to access truthful information and undermining the fairness of elections. The Court reasoned that without regulation, AI-manipulated campaign imagery could distort voter perception, compromise informed decision-making, and erode the integrity of democratic processes, imposing restrictions on the use of AI-generated images in the elections.
excerpt: "That the sophistication of technology applied in campaign materials needs to be limited and given strict rules because it risks distorting the facts of the candidate's true self-image and can make the election contest merely an image-building competition that has no relevance to the vision - mission and ability of the participants to lead the position being contested. The masking of reality also risks making voters unable to distinguish between the true self-image of the Election Participants and the self-image that is merely engineered/fabricated. Furthermore, the use of self-images that do not correspond to the actual facts risks deceiving voters about the true self-image of the Election Participants."

summary: The petitioner argued that Meta acts as a de facto authority by processing personal data under a state-delegated function, failing to implement proactive AI-based mechanisms, which it uses for other features, to verify users’ ages and restrict harmful content, thereby violating children’s rights under Mexican and international law. However, the Supreme Court’s First Chamber ruled that the case lacks sufficient national importance or novelty to warrant attraction because existing jurisprudence on private actors’ authority-equivalence (especially the “intervención pública” doctrine) already provides a framework for lower courts to decide.

court: Buenos Aires Contencioso Administrativo y Tributario
caseName: Juzgado en lo Contencioso Administrativo y Tributario Nro. 25, 4/10/24
summary: A public prosecutor filed a collective action in Buenos Aires seeking to block websites that allow cloning of people’s faces and voices using AI, requesting registration of the case under the collective processes registry.
excerpt: "Corresponde ordenar en el marco de lo dispuesto por el Acuerdo Plenario No 4/2016, la inscripción en el Registro de Procesos Colectivos de la demanda instada por la fiscal de la Unidad Especializada en Litigios Complejos del Ministerio Público de la Ciudad Autónoma en virtud de la cual solicita que en ejercicio del poder de policia local el gobierno bloquee las páginas web que según sostiene, permitirían clonar el rostro y la voz de las personas mediante inteligencia artificial, máxime cuando se encuentra verificado que no existen otros procesos en los que se debatan cuestiones análogas”

summary: In Denegri v. Google, the Argentine Supreme Court reversed a lower decision that had partially upheld a “right to be forgotten” claim, ruling that Google was not obligated to de-index search results linking Natalia Denegri to past public scandals, emphasizing that search engines and their algorithms are constitutionally protected forms of freedom of expression. The Court affirmed that the ordering of information by search engine algorithms, even if not neutral and influenced by relevance criteria, is part of protected speech essential to public debate, and that suppressing truthful, public-interest content based on subjective offense or outdated relevance risks erasing collective memory and undermines democratic freedoms
excerpt: "          23) Que finalmente, más allá de que los fundamentos de la petición de la actora no alcancen para justificar el bloqueo de vínculos referidos a información de interés público, los planteos que ha efectuado, así como los temas debatidos en la audiencia pública vinculados con los criterios que utilizan los motores de búsqueda para determinar sus resultados –tales como el número de veces que las palabras-clave aparecen en el sitio, el lugar en el que aparecen, el título y la calidad del sitio, la cantidad de sitios que abrevan en tal lugar, el orden en el que los contenidos se presentan, entre otros factores− no pueden ser ignorados. Es así que el presente pronunciamiento no implica desconocer que el creciente uso de herramientas de tecnología informática y, en particular, de sistemas que podrían incluirse dentro de la categoría “Inteligencia Artificial” (IA), suscita numerosos interrogantes respecto de su campo de aplicación a la luz de los derechos fundamentales reconocidos en la Constitución Nacional y en los Tratados de Derechos Humanos, así como respecto de su incidencia en la ordenación del debate público. Aun cuando el tema no haya sido objeto de debate en la presente causa, cabe destacar la existencia de un foro de discusión mundial acerca del modo de compatibilizar los problemas que en algunas ocasiones podrían suscitarse entre los mencionados derechos y el funcionamiento de los sistemas de algoritmos (como ejemplo de los temas en debate en la materia, puede consultarse las “Directrices Éticas para una IA fiable”, Grupo Independiente de Expertos de Alto Nivel sobre Inteligencia Artificial creado por la Comisión Europea en junio de 2018)”. En este marco, y específicamente referido a los criterios de ordenamiento de la información por parte de los buscadores, la representación de la demandada sostuvo en la audiencia que el modo en que el algoritmo ordena los resultados “no necesariamente sigue una cronología. Sale lo que Google estima que es más relevante para ese usuario. Aparte es distinto si uno lo busca en Argentina, si lo busca en Estados Unidos, porque lo relevante va a ser distinto. […] Es una cosa complejísima (…)”. Posteriormente agregó que no era ese un criterio “neutro” (respuesta del Doctor Grondona p. 46 y 50 de la versión taquigráfica de la audiencia).  En base a la forma en que Google manifestó que aparecen los resultados, se podría generar un cierto perfil de las personas que podría condicionar la composición de lugar que el internauta se hará de la identidad de la persona auscultada. De ahí la necesidad de asumir hacia el futuro la problemática de ciertos aspectos del funcionamiento de los algoritmos de los que se sirven los motores de búsqueda, para que resulten más entendibles y transparentes para los usuarios, hoy sujetos a la decisión de aquellos.”

court: Agencia Española de Protección de Datos
summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) dismissed complaints against Universidad Internacional de La Rioja for using laptop cameras and a second camera setup to verify students’ identity during online exams, finding no unlawful processing of biometric data or disproportionate intrusion. The DPA confirmed that no facial recognition or biometric processing occurred, and that identity verification was based on public interest (Article 6(1)(e) GDPR), not consent; moreover, it held that the measures taken, including impact assessments and transparency towards students, adequately minimized data protection risks and respected proportionality.
excerpt:
"Sobre la utilización de técnicas de reconocimiento facial, tras verificar
autenticidad del certificado aportado por la empresa SMOWL, queda constatado que
no se realizan tratamientos de categorías especiales de datos y no aplican técnicas de
reconocimiento facial. Tras verificar la autenticidad de los certificados aportados por la empresa
SMOWL, queda constatado que se ha eliminado la información que se aportaba (por
error) en el proceso de registro del alumno en el sistema, en concreto la información
errónea aportada sobre la base de legitimación y sobre el almacenamiento de modelos
biométricos. La base de legitimación del tratamiento no es el consentimiento, sino que
es necesario para el cumplimiento de una misión realizada en interés público o en el
ejercicio de poderes públicos conferidos al responsable del tratamiento, la UNIR
Quedando también constatado que UNIR no almacena modelos biométricos.”

court: Agencia Española de Protección de Datos
summary: The Spanish DPA fined GSMA €200,000 for using a facial recognition system for event accreditation without conducting a proper risk assessment.
excerpt:
"El tratamiento de reconocimiento facial presenta altos riesgos para los derechos y
libertades fundamentales y antes de implantar un proyecto de tratamiento de datos,
siempre y cuando sea probable que el mismo suponga un riesgo significativo para los
derechos y libertades de las personas, es preciso auditar su funcionamiento, no de
forma aislada sino en el marco del tratamiento concreto en que se va a emplear. Da-
das las consecuencias potencialmente perjudiciales para las personas afectadas, de-
berán cumplirse requisitos más rigurosos en el proceso de evaluación de impacto de
cualquier medida que interfiera con la dignidad de una persona, en términos de cues-
tionamiento de la necesidad y proporcionalidad, así como de las posibilidades de los
individuos para ejercer su derecho a la protección de datos”

court: Agencia Española de Protección de Datos
summary: The Spanish DPA issued an advisory opinion stating that the State Commission Against Violence in Sport could not lawfully implement biometric identification systems for football stadium access under Article 9(2)(g) GDPR. The DPA held that biometric identification is a highly intrusive processing of special categories of data and that no sufficiently specific law establishing a substantial public interest and adequate safeguards existed to justify it.
excerpt:
"Esta Agencia ha tenido ocasión de pronunciarse, en diversas ocasiones,
respecto de los requisitos establecidos por el artículo 9.2.g) del RGPD para
poder amparar los tratamientos de datos biométricos, singularmente respecto
de los basados en el reconocimiento facial, dada la proliferación de propuestas
recibidas en relación con los mismos desde ámbitos diferentes, lo que pone de manifiesto el interés creciente en utilizar estos sistemas y la constante
preocupación de esta autoridad de control, al tratarse de sistemas de
identificación muy intrusivos para los derechos y libertades fundamentales de
las personas físicas”.

court: Agencia Española de Protección de Datos
summary:
Equifax scraped public data about individuals from official sources without consent and used it in its credit databases, including inaccurate and outdated information, refusing some erasure requests.
The Spanish DPA found that Equifax violated GDPR by processing public data for incompatible purposes without a lawful basis, breaching purpose limitation, lawfulness, accuracy, data minimization, and transparency obligations. Since the information was originally collected for public notification, not private financial assessments, and individuals could not reasonably expect its reuse, the DPA ruled that the fundamental right to data protection outweighed Equifax’s claimed legitimate interests.
excerpt:
"2. Con el propósito de determinar si el tratamiento de los datos de los reclamantes que
ha efectuado EQUIFAX a través del FIJ es o no respetuoso con el principio previsto en
el artículo 5.1.b) RGPD, el punto de partida ha de ser el origen de los datos tratados.
Como ya se ha indicado los datos de los reclamantes se obtuvieron, en su gran
mayoría, del BOE, más exactamente del Tablón Edictal Único del BOE (TEU-BOE); de
los diarios oficiales de las Comunidades Autónomas; de los Boletines Provinciales
(BOP) y a través de la sede electrónica o física de organismos o entidades de Derecho
Público. El hecho de que los datos de los reclamantes procedan de fuentes públicas,
básicamente de diarios y boletines oficiales, evidencia que éstos habían sido objeto de
un tratamiento anterior con una finalidad determinada.”

court: Agencia Española de Protección de Datos
summary: Mercadona used facial recognition AI in supermarkets to scan all customers to spot banned individuals. The Spanish DPA found that Mercadona unlawfully processed special categories of biometric data without a valid legal basis or adequate safeguards, violating GDPR principles on necessity, proportionality, minimization, and transparency. Facial recognition was deemed a disproportionate, high-risk AI technology that subjected all individuals, including non-convicted and vulnerable persons, to mass surveillance without justification.
excerpt:
"El tratamiento ahora analizado se caracteriza por: - Utilizar datos biométricos, que son categorías especiales de datos del art.
9 del RGPD (uno-a-varios) sobre los que recae una prohibición general de
utilización, a salvo excepción prevista en la propia norma. Este tratamiento es,
por tanto, excepcional.
- Se produce a distancia en un espacio de acceso al público en general.
- Es un tratamiento continuado que contrasta los datos recogidos con otros
almacenados en una base de datos.
- Es un tratamiento automático.
- Es de riesgo extremadamente elevado (inaceptable) al poder derivar en
una vigilancia masiva e indiscriminada.
- Como podemos comprobar el tratamiento de datos utilizando
identificación biométrica remota es automático, y el dato biométrico se capta (se
trata) automáticamente; por ello se considera de riesgo extremadamente elevado
(inaceptable) este tratamiento de datos."

court: Agencia Española de Protección de Datos
summary: LaLiga was fined for mandating biometric access controls like fingerprint and facial recognition at stadiums without first conducting the required data protection impact assessment.

court: Agencia Española de Protección de Datos
summary: The Spanish DPA fined Club Atlético Osasuna €200,000 because its voluntary facial recognition system for stadium access, though based on consent, unlawfully processed excessive biometric data without necessity, violating GDPR principles.

court: Agencia Española de Protección de Datos
summary: The Spanish DPA fined a company €220,000 for unlawfully using a facial recognition system to track employees’ attendance without a valid legal basis, necessity, or proper data protection impact assessment, violating GDPR rules on biometric data processing.

caseName: Imponen la medida de libertad vigilada durante un año a los 15 menores acusados de manipular y difundir imágenes de menores desnudas en Badajoz
summary: Fifteen minors in Badajoz were sentenced to one year of probation for using AI applications to manipulate images by superimposing girls’ faces from social media onto naked bodies and sharing them via WhatsApp groups.

A Portuguese appellate court (TRP) recognized the existence of an employment relationship between a delivery driver and a digital platform, where the platform managed work through an app using algorithmic systems and real-time geolocation. Despite certain autonomous elements, the court found that the algorithmic control, client ownership, price-setting, real-time tracking, and sanctioning powers exercised by the platform demonstrated a modern form of subordination compatible with the digital era, thus qualifying the relationship as employment.
excerpt: "IV - O estafeta não dispõe de clientes próprios e insere-se numa organização produtiva externa (a da plataforma digital); não assume riscos de ganhos ou perdas; o critério de remuneração é, em última análise, definido pela plataforma; esta controla a prestação do serviço em tempo real, através da gestão algorítmica e de sistemas de geolocalização, detém poderes sancionatórios, podendo, inclusive, desativar a conta do estafeta.”

summary: The bank wrongly listed a person as a risky cheque user due to a system error, claiming the mistake was caused by an automatic communication process without human verification, linked to flaws in its internal technological organization. The court held that even if errors result from automated systems, banks are fully responsible for verifying sensitive information before transmission, as current technology (including AI systems) still fundamentally depends on human oversight and programming, making negligence attributable to the bank.
excerpt:
"Afirmar que o facto tem de ser voluntário não é o mesmo que defender que ele tem de ser intencional, deliberado, directamente desejado. O facto é voluntário desde que seja susceptível de ser imputado à vontade do agente, ou seja, desde que o agente possua o poder de o controlar. Não é voluntário o acto praticado, por exemplo, sob hipnose, mas já é voluntário o acto praticado por falta da diligência necessária para evitar o que o agente podia humanamente evitar ou por erro de avaliação ou pressuposição.
É manifesto que no caso o réu praticou um facto, isto é, teve uma actuação: comunicou ao Banco de Portugal que determinadas pessoas, supostamente ambas titulares de uma conta bancária aberta numa sua agência, não haviam procedido à regularização do saque de um cheque para cujo pagamento não havia fundos suficientes. 
É igualmente inequívoco que se tratou de um acto voluntário, na medida em que, ainda que na origem do mesmo haja estado uma falha informática do réu, o seu sistema informático é naturalmente resultado da diligência posta na sua programação, na sua fiscalização e vigilância, sendo, nessa medida, fruto da sua própria vontade, do seu exclusivo critério de organização para a prossecução dos seus objectivos, uma vez que, pelo menos no estado actual da tecnologia, ao que saibamos, ainda não existem sistema de inteligência artificial capazes, eles mesmos, de criarem sistemas informáticos que pratiquem actos.
"

summary: A Portuguese judge refused to apply laws mandating electronic distribution of court cases via an algorithm developed and maintained by the Ministry of Justice, arguing it violated judicial independence and the separation of powers. The Constitutional Court held that the distribution algorithm’s use does not violate judicial independence or the separation of powers because it remains a pre-judicial administrative act..
excerpt:
"57.  Ora, o processamento de grandes quantidades de dados por computadores cada vez mais potentes e usando algoritmos cada vez mais sofisticados é uma realidade em franco crescimento.
58.  No âmbito judiciário a questão já não é saber se somos a favor ou contra os algoritmos, mas sim como enquadrá-los na atividade jurisdicional sem desvirtuar a sua essência e a sua função. 
59.  Conforme definiu José Joaquim F. Oliveira Martins, «Direito e Processo do Trabalho e Inteligência Artificial (Primeiras reflexões a partir do Direito Português» in AA. VV, coord. de Selma Carloto, Inteligência Artificial nas Relações de Trabalho, São Paulo, 2022, p. 239, “um algoritmo é tão só um procedimento informatizado destinado a resolver certos problemas ou a atingir determinados objetivos. Traduz-se tipicamente numa “sequência de instruções que diz a um computador o que fazer e, para atingir uma finalidade, transforma dados de entrada (input) em resultados humanamente apreensíveis (output)” – INÊS DA SILVA COSTA, A proteção da pessoa na era dos big data: a opacidade do algoritmo e as decisões automatizadas, p. 40, disponível em https://cije.up.pt/client/files/0000000001/4-ines-costa_1677.pdf”.
60.  Ora, a simples descrição dos algoritmos parece algo inútil, dado que essa descrição se deverá limitar, aparentemente, a explicitar, em linguagem comum, a forma geral como funcionam esses algoritmos, sem que através dessa descrição se possa perceber, sem mais, se esses algoritmos correspondem ao aí descrito e ao regime legal acabado de descrever e se cumprem as exigências legais de aleatoriedade e de igualação do serviço entre juízes.
“

summary:
An architect claimed that his idea for using an existing viaduct for a metro line should be protected as a copyrighted work, alleging unauthorized use by others.
The court held that copyright protects only original, individual expressions that are perceptible to others, not mere ideas or technical solutions; in explaining the necessity of human intellectual creation, the court noted that if a work is created solely by a machine (such as by artificial intelligence), it would not be eligible for copyright protection under current law because there would be no human author.
excerpt: "Quanto às obras geradas por computadores, também vários problemas têm sido colocados. O computador permite automatizar o processo de criação e introduzir variáveis aleatórias, o que pode conduzir a que se duvide da existência de uma criação humana. Se a na medida em que as técnicas da inteligência artificial vierem a permitir a criação da obra exclusivamente pela máquina, naturalmente que não estaremos perante obras protegidas pelo direito de autor, porque não há autor. Em todos os casos, todavia em que é uma pessoa que está na origem da obra deverá poderá ser protegida pelo direito de autor. LUCAS e LUCAS afirmam: "Tout au plus peat-on subordonner l'attrbuition du monopole d'auteur à la condition que cette personne ait eu une "notion suffisante du resultat à atteinder", quitte à entendre l'exigence de maniere compréhensive pour les versions expressemént revendiquées par elle (ob. cit., p,71).”

summary: Leadzai uses AI-based software to automate the creation and management of digital marketing campaigns, but it does not offer AI software as a standalone product or a platform (PaaS); it offers a marketing service that employs AI internally. The court found that merely using AI inside a service does not transform the service into an AI product protected by Feedzai’s trademarks, because the AI is only an internal tool for delivering marketing outcomes, not the product being offered to the public.
excerpt:
"2. Também não é pelo facto do software disponibilizado pela Recorrida aos consumidores efetivamente envolver o uso de inteligência artificial (IA) que se pode concluir por um modelo PaaS. 
3. Por fim, também não é pelo facto do software empregar IA que os serviços prestados pela Recorrida deixam de ser qualificáveis como serviços de publicidade e marketing digital. O fim último da utilização do programa pelos consumidores é sempre a de gerar e gerir companhas de publicidade e marketing digital. Ou seja, o programa disponibilizado pela Recorrida aos clientes trata de um mero meio ou instrumento para tal fim.
4. Neste contexto, inexiste afinidade entre os serviços efetivamente prestados pela Recorrida com o uso do sinal controverso “LEADZAI”, e os produtos e serviços assinalados pelas marcas prioritárias da Recorrente “FEEDZAI”, em especial, das Classes 9 (nomeadamente, software de inteligência artificial) e 42 da Classificação de Nice (nomeadamente, PaaS). Inexistindo tal afinidade forçoso é concluir que inexiste risco de confusão entre os sinais, improcedendo, assim, o recurso.
“

court: Comissão Nacional de Proteção de Dados
summary: The Portuguese DPA (CNPD) found that an educational institution’s use of the AI-powered proctoring app Respondus Monitor, which performed continuous facial detection, movement analysis, device monitoring, and automated behavioral profiling during online exams, infringed data protection rules. The CNPD held that the intrusive AI monitoring and opaque profiling violated the principles of lawfulness, purpose limitation, and data minimization under the GDPR, noting that the institution failed to justify the necessity and proportionality of such automated processing, and that transfers of biometric and other data to the U.S. lacked valid safeguards after Schrems II.
excerpt:
"44. Esta é uma questão-chave por duas ordens de razão. Por um lado, a justificação do tratamento de dados
associado à utilização das duas aplicações Respondus,|
apenas se cinge à necessidade de realizar avaliações à distância e com integridade (o que se pressupõe que o
s i s t e m a l também assegure), não sendo apresentados argumentos concretos para o recurso às
ferramentas da Respondus. Além disso, tratando-se de duas aplicações distintas, sendo que a "Respondus
Lockdown Browser" pode funcionar por si só, não são adiantados motivos para recorrer também à aplicação
"Respondus Monitor", em complemento da aplicação BLR. Por conseguinte, do ponto de vista da finalidade do
tratamento de dados, não é esta suficientemente determinada e explícita, conforme exigido pelo artigo 5.°, n.°
1, alínea b), do RGPD, de modo a conferir previsibilidade quanto às situações em que será necessário, em
alternativa à plataforma institucionali utilizar as aplicações Respondus. Com efeito, essa é uma
decisão que é deixada ao arbítrio dos coordenadores das unidades orgânicas, sem se especificar quais os
critérios atendíveis para fundamentar tal decisão. Deste modo, a utilização ou não daquelas aplicações, que
implicam um tratamento de dados pessoais acrescido e de elevado grau de intrusão na privacidade dos
estudantes, não está sujeita a critérios objetivos, uniformes e escrutináveis. Por isso mesmo, é geradora de
discriminação.”

court: Superior Court of Justice of Navarra
summary:
The Superior Court of Justice of Navarra (TSJNA) analyzed a case where a lawyer mistakenly cited Colombian law in a Spanish complaint after relying on erroneous information generated by ChatGPT.
The TSJNA held that while no fine would be imposed due to the novelty of AI use and the lawyer’s prompt acknowledgment of error, it emphasized that lawyers remain fully responsible for verifying AI-generated content, warning of the ethical, legal, and professional risks posed by uncritical reliance on AI hallucinations.

caseName: Data Protection Commission Announces commencement of inquiry into X Internet Unlimited Company (XIUC)
summary: The Irish Data Protection Commission (DPC) announced an inquiry into X Internet Unlimited Company (XIUC) over the use of publicly accessible posts from EU/EEA users on the X platform to train Grok Large Language Models (LLMs).

caseName: Data Protection Commission launches inquiry into Google AI model
summary: On 12 September 2024, the Irish Data Protection Commission (DPC) launched a cross-border inquiry into Google Ireland Limited regarding the processing of EU/EEA users’ personal data for developing its foundational AI model, PaLM 2.

caseName: Irish Data Protection Commission fines LinkedIn Ireland €310 million
summary: The Irish DPC fined LinkedIn €310 million for unlawfully processing personal data for behavioural analysis and targeted advertising based on a complaint initially filed by La Quadrature du Net. The DPC found that LinkedIn’s use of personal data for profiling lacked a valid legal basis under the GDPR, as user consent was neither freely given nor sufficiently informed, legitimate interests were overridden by users’ rights, and contractual necessity did not apply.

caseName: In the matter of LB, a complainant, concerning a complaint directed against Meta Platforms Ireland
summary: The Irish DPC fined Meta €210 million after finding that Facebook unlawfully processed personal data for behavioural advertising based on an invalid reliance on contractual necessity instead of proper consent. The DPC, following the EDPB’s binding decision, held that behavioural advertising was not necessary for the Facebook contract, that Meta lacked a valid legal basis under Article 6 GDPR, and that its practices violated transparency and fairness principles, exploiting informational asymmetries and user dependency.
excerpt:
"4.8 More specifically, insofar as the Complaint refers to particular processing activities, it has a specific
focus on data processed to facilitate behavioural advertising. This will accordingly be the focus of
the analysis in this Decision.
4.9 In order to ensure that this Inquiry has a reasonable degree of specificity, I will therefore consider
whether Facebook can, in principle, rely on Article 6(1)(b) GDPR for processing under the contract,
including and in particular in the context of behavioural advertising.”

caseName: Ziff Davis, IGN Entertainment and Everyday Health Media v. OpenAI
summary: The complainants allege OpenAI’s model development infringed on their copyrights.

caseName: Parker v. Forsyth NNO and Others
summary: The plaintiff’s attorneys presented cases gathered through ChatGPT which did not, in fact, exist. Due to the time spent by the defendant’s attorneys to locate the cases, costs were redeemed.
excerpt:
"[90] In this age of instant gratification, this incident serves as a timely reminder to, at least, the lawyers involved in this matter that when it comes to legal research, the efficiency of modern technology still needs to be infused with a dose of good old-fashioned independent reading. Courts expect lawyers to bring a legally-independent and questioning mind to bear on, especially, novel legal matters, and certainly not to merely repeat in parrot-fashion, the unverified research of a chatbot.

[91] Although the plaintiff’s attorneys did not intend to mislead anyone, the inevitable result of this debacle was that the Defendants’ attorneys were indeed misled into thinking that these authorities were real. As a result, they would have invested a significant amount of time and effort in their futile attempts at tracking down these cases. The hearing of the 22nd of May 2023 was intended for the specific purpose of receiving the relevant case-law authority that turned out not to exist. The costs order sought by the Defendants in this regard is not unreasonable. Indeed, the court does not even consider it to be punitive. It is simply appropriate. The embarrassment associated with this incident is probably sufficient punishment for the Plaintiff’s attorneys.
“

summary: The plaintiff’s attorneys presented cases gathered through ChatGPT which did not, in fact, exist. The case was referred for the Legal Practice Council for investigation and a de bonis propiis costs order was determined.
excerpt:
"my view, relying on AI technologies when doing legal research is irresponsible and downright unprofessional.
 
[51]    The circumstances of the present matter is significantly more serious than those in Parker or any of the other cases referred to in Van Eck’s article. The facts actually speak for themselves. I will therefore make an order that my judgment be referred to the Legal Practice Council for investigation and further action.”

summary: The plaintiff drafted his arguments using Google. The Court noted they were better than some professionally drafted defenses and that “lawyers need to watch out for artificial intelligence”.
excerpt: “[30]         Finally, I must mention Mr Makunga’s heads of argument. He filed heads of argument which contained extensive reference to case law. In cross-examination, he was asked whether he prepared them himself. He said he had, relying only on the assistance of Google. Mr McLachlan expressed his disbelief. In argument he told me that many of his colleagues were equally incredulous and were convinced only a lawyer could have drafted the heads. I admit that I have seen worse heads of argument prepared by members of the Bar. But this does not evince dishonesty to me. Rather, it shows Mr Makunga’s perseverance and commitment, and the fact that lawyers need to watch out for artificial intelligence. One day soon, the computers are coming for our jobs."

summary: A defense lawyer used generative AI to produce a criminal appeal filled with 43 fabricated jurisprudential references and fictitious court decisions, which the judge detected as entirely false The court ruled the appeal inadmissible because relying on AI-generated, unchecked fabrications undermines the seriousness of judicial proceedings and violates ethical duties, and makes it impossible to separate true arguments from falsehoods, which led the appeal to be rejected.
excerpt: "Todas elas, no entanto, são criações de alguma (des)inteligência artificial. Esta Corte não tem nenhum desembargador chamado Fábio André Munhoz ou João Augusto Simões (não existe nenhum desembargador no país com esses nomes). Já o Desembargador João Pedro Gebran Neto integra o TRF-4 e não esta Corte. Também, o Desembargador Paulo Roberto Vasconcelos já se aposentou bastante tempo antes das datas mencionadas nos “julgados”.Os números dos “processos” desta Corte também são curiosos: “1234-56”; “3456-78”; “12345-67”; “6543-21”; “12346-78”; “9876-34”.Nem um único julgado do STJ e do STF mencionados é fidedigno.Ou seja, o recurso todo foi feito com o uso de IA com a finalidade de induzir o colegiado em erro.Todavia, como se sabe, apenas e unicamente o advogado tem capacidade postulatória. Ainda não chegamos ao ponto de conceder tal benefício a sistemas computacionais. O advogado tem obrigação de, no mínimo, revisar as peças feitas com o uso dessas ferramentas.E a obrigatoriedade dessa revisão é simples: o Poder Judiciário não está brincando de julgar recursos! E mais! Ao agir assim, o advogado não mostra a seriedade que o caso e o seu cliente exigem e merecem.Sem dúvidas, para análise do mérito recursal, seria preciso separar o “joio do trigo”, as alegações verdadeiras das alegações falsas, o que se torna inviável diante de tamanha falta de técnica.Por consequência, o recurso não pode ser conhecido.”

summary: The claimant’s Instagram account was hacked, and a video of her was manipulated using artificial intelligence to promote a scam, leading to moral damages. The court recognized that the unauthorized AI manipulation of the video and Facebook’s inertia in resolving the situation constituted a service failure justifying moral damages, and it maintained the compensation amount at R$ 5,000, applying principles of proportionality and reasonableness.

Excerpts of a contract written in Spanish were translated for the judgment using Microsoft’s Copilot, an officially adopted AI tool by the court. The court reasoned the AI-assisted translations complied with the requirement to use Portuguese in judicial acts under Article 192 of the Code of Civil Procedure.
excerpt:
"Os trechos eventualmente copiados do instrumento para a fundamentação deste acórdão serão traduzidos livremente via Copilot - assistente de inteligência artificial (IA) da Microsoft, programa oficialmente utilizado por este Tribunal - somente para fins de cumprimento do art. 192 do CPC.
“

caseName: Bester N.O and Others v Mirror Trading International
summary: The court found, based on the unrebutted evidence, that the AI bot the respondent alleged it used to trade never existed, no trading profits were generated through AI, and these false representations were part of a broader fraudulent scheme, rendering the entire business model illegal and unlawful.
excerpt:
"[90] There are consequently no bona fide dispute of fact and on the evidence, I find that Steynberg did not use an  artificial intelligence  bot to achieve the alleged incredible trading results and that he did not transfer bitcoin deposited by investors held in a pooled account at FXChoice to an unregulated broker named Trade 300. It follows that the representations made by Steynberg and the management of MTI in this regard were false.

[91] The false representations pertaining to Trade 300 and the  artificial intelligence  bot, in my view, on a balance of probabilities, show that the business of MTI was fraudulent. I agree with the applicants that the fraud perpetrated by Steynberg and MTI were not isolated incidences but rather fundamental aspects of the structure of the business and as such tainted the business operations of MTI as a whole.

“

caseName: Faqirzada and Others v Minister of Home Affairs and Others
summary: AI was used to translate a warrant issued by a terrorist organization for use in immigration proceedings.

The court considered a defamation dispute where concerns were raised about the future accessibility of judicial decisions related to minor children through AI search technologies, prompting the judge to redact the parties’ identities.
excerpt: "[75] First, I should explain why, in the heading of the judgment and in my discussion above, I have avoided identifying the applicant, respondent, and the respondent’s ex-wife (ie, Ms T). I raised the issue of possible redaction with counsel for both parties, because I was uncomfortable with the idea that the minor children of the respondent and Ms T could either be identified themselves, or could identity their parents (when they become old enough to trawl the internet for themselves or, more likely, with the help of  artificial intelligence ) by coming across the judgment. Mr Bester submitted that redaction would be appropriate, and I did not understand Mr Van Nieuwenhuizen to have a difficulty with that. I am mindful of the need for justice to be done in public, but I see no public interest in revealing the identities of the parties in a case such as this. Or, to be precise, I see no public interest strong enough to trump the goal of protecting the minor children.”

summary: While addressing a damages claim for loss of income, the judge briefly noted that artificial intelligence could potentially assist in improving the precision of contingency calculations in the future.
excerpt: "[79] When all is said and done, the determination of the general contingency deduction remains a frustratingly imprecise exercise. The opinions of industrial psychologists, occupational therapists, and other medical professionals, as well as the methods and calculations of actuaries, undoubtedly assist the court. It may well be that the task could be aided and enhanced in future by the benefits of artificial intelligence (dare it be spoken), provided that there is proper adherence to the principles of evidence and procedure. Nevertheless, the determination of the correct deduction remains, for now, more of an art than a science.”

court: Court of Appeal of the Republic of Singapore
caseName: Quoine Pte Ltd v. B2C2 Ltd.
summary: Cryptocurrency trades were executed automatically by deterministic algorithms after Quoine’s platform malfunctioned, causing trades at extreme prices without human intervention or contemporaneous knowledge by the traders. The court ruled that when contracts are formed through algorithmic trading, the relevant knowledge for unilateral mistake must be assessed based on the programmers’ intent at the time of programming and up to contract formation. Since B2C2’s programmer did not foresee or intend to exploit counterparties’ mistakes, there was no operative unilateral mistake or unconscionability, and the contracts remained valid.
excerpt:
"97 This was also the view of the Judge and it drove him, in our judgment, inevitably, to adopt a certain analytical model when considering the issue of unilateral mistake. Specifically, he refused to consider the matter by reference to what the position would have been and what the contracting parties were likely to have known, intended and agreed had they had face-to-face negotiations at a hypothetical meeting on the “floor of the exchange” to enter into the Trading Contracts, at the time these were entered into, because this was simply not how they had agreed to form their contracts. Instead, they had decided to form contracts using the relevant deterministic algorithms (see Judgment at [200] and [204]). We agree with this characterisation of the parties’ method of contracting and we think it would be wholly artificial to recast the relevant matrix of fact, which was one where the contracting parties did not in fact know beforehand that they were going to enter into the Trading Contracts or their terms, and were content to abide by what the relevant algorithms did at least as long as this was within the ambit of their programmed parameters. We also agree with the Judge that it follows from this that in cases where contracts are made by way of deterministic algorithms, any analysis concerning knowledge of a mistake or unconscionably taking advantage of one must be done by reference to the state of mind of the programmers of the algorithms at the time of the programming (see Judgment at [211]).
98 As we have noted at [15] above, a deterministic computer program or algorithm is bound by the parameters set by the programmer, and can (and generally will) only do what the programmer has programmed it to do. Given a particular input, it will produce a particular output; on each occasion, the output should and will be the same if the former does not change. Therefore, when it comes to assessing the state of knowledge that is to be attributed to the parties at the time of a contract made by way of deterministic algorithms, the relevant inquiry cannot be directed at the parties themselves, who had no knowledge of or direct personal involvement in the formation of the contract. Rather, working backwards from the output that emanated from the programs, we are driven to assess the relevant state of knowledge by examining that of the programmers. This approach is consistent with that which was advocated by Prof Goh.
99 Apart from determining whose knowledge is relevant, it is also important to consider the relevant time for assessing that person’s knowledge. In our judgment, the relevant time frame within which we should assess the knowledge of a programmer or the person running the algorithm would be from the point of programming up to the point that the relevant contract is formed. As Prof Goh noted, the point of programming is when the programmer’s knowledge is the most concretised. The question can first be framed in this way: if the algorithm was programmed to produce a particular output, why was this done? But the inquiry cannot end there and must extend past that point of time because there may be situations where a programmer or the person running the algorithm who did not contemplate the relevant mistake at the point of programming came to learn of it subsequently before the contract had been formed, and yet allowed the algorithm to continue running, intending thereby to take advantage of the mistake. In such a case, it would be wrong to ignore the subsequent acquisition of knowledge. This is why it is appropriate to have regard to the state of knowledge up to the time of the contract.
“

summary:
The decision notes that platforms like Uber do not have autonomous will comparable to human decision-making, at least at the current stage of AI development.
Therefore, the analysis of the relationship must focus on the real execution of the work rather than on the platform’s formal role or contractual labels.
excerpt: "En concreto, la parte demandada invoca al apelar como distingo que fue el actor quien “ buscó contratar a UBER”, argumento que carece de toda relevancia, no es relevante quien “buscara” se ha de inferir que invocándose por la demandada que lo relevante es la plataforma, las plataformas no “buscan” a nadie están disponibles y determinados sujetos se vinculan con las empresas titulares de las plataformas, las plataformas no son personas jurídicas y no tienen voluntad propia, equiparable a los procesos de decisión humanos, al menos en el actual estadio del desarrollo de la inteligencia artificial. Lo que se ofrece por la demandada a través de la plataforma es un contrato de adhesión. Por lo tanto en ello reside lo que resulta relevante jurídicamente, en la forma y contenido del contrato. A las pautas ya referidas señaladas por la doctrina, solo cabe agregar que en punto a analizar la modalidad de vinculación resulta relevante tomar en cuenta si el modo de contratación en la cual el sujeto que presta trabajo carece de toda posibilidad de incidencia o negociación, por el mecanismo utilizado de acuerdo mediante “clic” a una forma pre redactada y de autoría unilateral de la demandada, ofrece respecto de la actividad, trabajo humano prestado por quien adhiere alguna ventaja concreta respecto de otras modalidades típicas para la prestación de la misma tarea. Es decir cabe preguntarse qué beneficio obtendría quien opta por adherir a la forma ofrecida por UBER. Nótese que UBER no paga ninguno de los costos que el conductor se obliga a asumir, no efectúa inversión alguna, y no paga beneficios sociales correspondientes a los trabajadores. Pero percibe un porcentaje que la propia demandada admite que se ubique en aproximadamente un 30% del producido bruto del trabajo del actor. Paralelamente, lo que resulta medular no es la denominación que las partes, en el caso la parte demandada y por simple adhesión la parte que presta trabajo, sino la realidad de lo actuado por las partes en la etapa de ejecución de la prestación de trabajo. Ello incluso desde la perspectiva del Código Civil, artículo 1301.
