summary: A man under investigation for rape of a vulnerable person has requested the removal of Facebook posts made by family members of the alleged victim, alleging a violation of his honor and image. The court recognized the use of algorithms and artificial intelligence by the platform to boost the viralization of sensationalist content, identifying an economic interest in spreading hatred, and ordered measures to contain the spread of content.
excerpt: "Em suma, a medida de exclusão dos posts e perfis dos usuários pretendida pelo agravante implicaria flagrante constrangimento à liberdade de expressão dos usuários da rede social.4. A controversa política adotada pelas poderosas redes sociais mundo afora (Google, Facebook, Twitter, etc), no sentido de utilizar os mecanismos da inteligência artificial (algoritmos) para incentivar a navegação dos usuários nas respectivas redes e, assim, majorar suas receitas com publicidade e outras fontes, evidencia a verossimilhança da alegação acerca da indevida disseminação do ódio nos ambientes virtuais, fato que sabidamente vem abalando o próprio equilíbrio das sociedades e democracias ao redor do globo, notadamente em razão da manipulação da opinião e confrontamento das pessoas uma contra as outras. (...) Assim, no caso, ao tempo em que deve ser resgardado o direito dos usuários de se manifestarem livremente quanto ao suposto crime praticado pelo agravante, considero que a replicação, disseminação, viralização do conteúdo publicado por um universo incontrolável de pessoas que não têm qualquer relação com a opinião originalmente emitida representa indevida extrapolação da liberdade de expressão e, como tal, abuso de direito, passível de censura judicial."

summary: The court recognized the financial institution's failure to detect, even with the use of artificial intelligence, atypical transactions that differed from the client's profile, showing a deficiency in the duty of security and giving rise to restitution of the amounts.
excerpt: "Ora, é cediço que o sistema de cartão de crédito possui inteligência artificial e quando as transações financeiras de determinado cliente se mostram incomum a compra não é liberada automaticamente"

summary: The court recognized the financial institution's failure to detect, even with the use of artificial intelligence, atypical transactions that differed from the client's profile, showing a deficiency in the duty of security and giving rise to restitution of the amounts.
excerpt: "Ao seguir as instruções de falso colaborador do banco, a parte foi induzida em erro por alto grau de dissimulação, sem que o Banco, repise-se, tenha adotado providências de paralisia do serviço de transferência, mediante o uso de procedimentos limitadores de segurança e da moderna inteligência artificial."

summary: The court recognized the financial institution's failure to detect, even with the use of artificial intelligence, atypical transactions that differed from the client's profile, showing a deficiency in the duty of security and giving rise to restitution of the amounts.
excerpt: "Apesar de seguir as instruções de falso colaborador do banco, a parte foi induzida em erro por alto grau de dissimulação, sem que o Banco, repise-se, tenha adotado providências de paralisia do serviço de transferência (pix e transferências entre bancos), com outros procedimentos limitadores de segurança e uso mais efetivo da moderna inteligência artificial"

summary: Non-existent judgments were added, with a fine for bad faith litigation.
excerpt: "As razões de apelo indicam fortemente o uso de ferramentas de inteligência artificial generativa, das quais são exemplos o ChatGPT e Gemini. Tal desconfiança é reforçada pela própria confissão do apelante do uso de fontes não confiáveis e sem verificação de autenticidade. A conduta claramente é temerária, uma vez que o próprio recorrente confessa que não verificou as fontes, sendo mais grave ainda o resultado, qual seja, falsas citações de Ministros do Supremo Tribunal Federal e Superior Tribunal de Justiça."

summary: A public examination candidate challenged the wording of an objective question, claiming an error in the substitution of the term “prevention” for “protection”, and relying on answers from artificial intelligence tools such as Google and ChatGPT. The Court upheld the exam board's template, stating that the substitution did not constitute a teratological error and that answers generated by AI do not have autonomous legal validity, as they are influenced by the user and are incapable of disproving legal and administrative grounds.
excerpt:
"No mais, nas razões recursais do presente Agravo Interno, o recorrente afirmou que "a própria inteligência artificial do Google" e o ChatGPT não consideram prevenção e proteção palavras sinônimas.
No entanto, o argumento não se sustenta.
Ora, sabe-se que a inteligência artificial - especificamente as do tipo generativa, como o ChatGPT - é treinada através de um processo iterativo com aquele que a utiliza, de modo que suas respostas sempre terão influência externa - no caso, do usuário da inteligência artificial.
"

summary:
“Passengers claimed that their luggage was lost on an international flight operated by TAP and Latam, presenting as proof screenshots of frustrated interactions with artificial intelligence on the company's WhatsApp.
The São Paulo Court of Justice dismissed the lawsuit for lack of proof of the loss and its formal communication to the companies, noting that the AI used by Latam does not replace the official channels for registering baggage irregularities.”
excerpt: "Ausente Registro de Irregularidade de Bagagem. Captura de tela indicando tentativa claramente frustrada, em canal oficial de atendimento, de registro do extravio com inteligência artificial da Latam, que orienta os autores ao registro de reclamação em site oficial, que não foi comprovada. Captura de tela de conversa com número desconhecido, não oficial, que supostamente os informou acerca da possibilidade de devolução das bagagens mediante assinatura de termo de isenção da Latam. Prova do extravio e de sua comunicação às rés que incumbia aos autores. Afastamento da condenação das rés. Recurso provido, para julgar a ação improcedente e condenar os autores ao pagamento da integralidade dos encargos sucumbenciais"

summary: The user had her TikTok account deactivated without prior notice, specific reason or proof of contractual infringement presented by Bytedance Brasil. The TJSP upheld the platform's conviction, pointing out that, given its technological apparatus based on algorithms and artificial intelligence, it was fully capable of identifying and presenting the conduct that would justify the penalty, and its omission was arbitrary.
excerpt:
"Como cediço, as empresas que operam plataformas digitais de redes
sociais possuem grande aparato tecnológico de armazenamento e processamento de
dados, não só para metrificar como também para, por meio de algoritmos e
inteligência artificial, influenciar os comportamentos de seus colaboradores.
Ora, nesse contexto, de rigor reconhecer que a requerida dispunha, sim,
de meios para indicar de forma precisa e detalhada informações a respeito das
supostas condutas da autora que culminaram na aplicação da penalidade de
banimento e cancelamento da conta permanente imposta."

summary: The court recognized the financial institution's failure to detect, even with the use of artificial intelligence, atypical transactions that differed from the client's profile, showing a deficiency in the duty of security and giving rise to restitution of the amounts.
excerpt: "Os bancos vêm automatizando cada vez mais os seus sistemas, substituindo a mão de obra humana pela tecnológica. Como consequência de tal conduta, o requerido possui obrigação de desenvolver inteligência artificial compatível com aquilo que oferece. Incumbia à instituição bancária detectar as transações suspeitas e tomar providências no sentido de confirmar sua regularidade ou bloqueá-las. Houve falha no sistema do banco, que não detectou a estranheza na operação, mesmo que o valor tenha superado o limite disponível pelos requerentes"

summary: The court recognized the financial institution's failure to detect, even with the use of artificial intelligence, atypical transactions that differed from the client's profile, showing a deficiency in the duty of security and giving rise to restitution of the amounts.
excerpt: "Ao automatizar o atendimento, substituindo a mão de obra humana pela tecnológica, o fornecedor de serviços tem obrigação de desenvolver inteligência artificial compatível com aquilo que oferece. O sistema do banco não detectou estranheza nas operações realizadas de forma sequencial, em valores incompatíveis ao perfil do autor e em curto espaço de tempo. O conjunto probatório revela falha na prestação dos serviços bancários."

summary: The court recognized the financial institution's failure to detect, even with the use of artificial intelligence, atypical transactions that differed from the client's profile, showing a deficiency in the duty of security and giving rise to restitution of the amounts.
excerpt: "Os bancos vêm automatizando cada vez mais os seus sistemas, substituindo a mão de obra humana pela tecnológica. Como consequência de tal conduta, o requerido possui obrigação de desenvolver inteligência artificial compatível com aquilo que oferece". Houve falha na prestação de serviços porque o banco não detectou estranheza das operações em que contemplaram, seguidamente, valores altos e incompatíveis ao perfil do autor. "

summary: The plaintiff filed a lawsuit against the website Jusbrasil, claiming that they used artificial intelligence to extract and display online data from lawsuits in which he was a party. The TJSP dismissed the appeal, holding that the automated extraction by AI of public information from official gazettes is lawful.
excerpt: "Informações atinentes unicamente ao nome das partes, ao Foro de tramitação e à natureza da lide. Numeração processual disponibilizada de maneira incompleta. Não disponibilização de outras informações. Divulgação de conteúdo extraído de órgãos do Poder Judiciário, automaticamente, por inteligência artificial. Direito da apelada em disponibilizar a informação."

summary: The digital influencer claimed that Instagram, using an artificial intelligence algorithm, applied a shadowban against him that significantly reduced the reach of his publications, damaging his professional activity. The TJSP denied the injunction for lack of sufficient credibility and emphasized that the allegation of improper use of AI must be examined in an adversarial manner.
excerpt: "Tutela de urgência voltada a compelir a ré a retomar a normal divulgação e publicidade de conteúdos postados pelo autor no respectivo perfil na plataforma "Instagram", por meio de "algoritmo de inteligência artificial". Indeferimento. Irresignação improcedente. Elementos dos autos não evidenciando juízo de verossimilhança bastante. Recomendável, de todo modo, que o pleito de antecipação de tutela seja analisado sob a égide do contraditório."

summary: The player filed a lawsuit against Bandai Namco and Google claiming that his Dragon Ball Legends account had been wrongfully banned after human opponents were repeatedly replaced by artificial intelligence during matches. The TJSP dismissed the appeal, holding that although there was no unequivocal proof of malicious intent, the abnormal frequency of AI activations indicated conduct that violated the game's terms of use, legitimizing the penalty applied.
excerpt: "Banimento da conta do autor no jogo Dragon Ball Legends. Violação dos termos de uso do jogo. Desconexões das partidas de batalhas, com substituição do oponente operado por humano para oponente operado por inteligência artificial. Autor que fez uso de subterfúgio para aumentar artificialmente sua pontuação no ranking em detrimento de outros jogadores. Perícia e contexto probatório dos autos que favorecem a tese das empresas requeridas. "

summary:
"Instagram deactivated the business account of a user with more than 500 thousand followers, generically alleging spam, without presenting evidence or specifying the offending conduct.
The Court recognized that, given the use of algorithms and artificial intelligence to detect violations, the platform had full technical conditions to identify and justify in detail the penalty imposed, making arbitrary deactivation without transparent motivation unacceptable, in violation of the Internet Civil Rights Framework and the principle of good faith."
excerpt: "Como cediço, as empresas que operam plataformas digitais de redes sociais possuem grande aparato tecnológico de armazenamento e processamento de dados, não só para metrificar como também para, por meio de algoritmos e inteligência artificial, influenciar os comportamentos de seus colaboradores. Nesse contexto, de rigor reconhecer que a requerida dispunha, sim, de meios para indicar de forma precisa e detalhada as informações a respeito das supostas condutas da autora que culminaram na aplicação da penalidade imposta. "

summary: The court recognized the financial institution's failure to detect, even with the use of artificial intelligence, atypical transactions that differed from the client's profile, showing a deficiency in the duty of security and giving rise to restitution of the amounts.
excerpt: "Na era da inteligência artificial e domínio dos algoritmos, injustificável a inexistência ou não utilização de meios usualmente empregados para identificar fraudes - Risco da atividade - Responsabilidade da instituição financeira pela desídia (falha do serviço) "

summary:
"The plaintiff filed a lawsuit to exhibit bank contracts without proving a prior administrative request to the financial institution, only presenting an email sent by a lawyer without a power of attorney with specific powers.
The Court reaffirmed that, especially in view of the processing of confidential data in a digital and artificial intelligence context, formal identification of the applicant and a valid power of attorney are essential."
excerpt:
"4 - Com efeito, informações bancárias são sigilosas e, portanto, somente poderiam ser fornecidas - mormente em tempos de inteligência artificial -, acaso formalmente requeridas, com identificação oficial do interessado, seja correntista ou advogado, bem como, apresentação de procuração outorgada pelo autor ao causídico integrante do escritório de advocacia solicitante.
"

summary: The court recognized the financial institution's failure to detect, even with the use of artificial intelligence, atypical transactions that differed from the client's profile, showing a deficiency in the duty of security and giving rise to restitution of the amounts.
excerpt: "A instituição financeira é responsável pela verificação de regularidade das transações e tem o dever de implementar mecanismos de confirmação adicional em relação à transações que escancaradamente fogem do perfil de movimentação do cliente, sendo que, no atual estágio de desenvolvimento da inteligência artificial é plenamente possível que o perfil de cada cliente seja automaticamente mapeado para identificação das movimentações atípicas, tanto em relação ao valor, frequência ou objeto que caracterize a atipicidade"

summary: The court recognized the financial institution's failure to detect, even with the use of artificial intelligence, atypical transactions that differed from the client's profile, showing a deficiency in the duty of security and giving rise to restitution of the amounts.
excerpt: "A instituição financeira é responsável pela verificação de regularidade das transações e tem o dever de implementar mecanismos de confirmação adicional em relação à transações que escancaradamente fogem do perfil de movimentação do cliente, sendo que, no atual estágio de desenvolvimento da inteligência artificial é plenamente possível que o perfil de cada cliente seja automaticamente mapeado para identificação das movimentações atípicas, tanto em relação ao valor, frequência ou objeto que caracterize a atipicidade"

summary: The court recognized the financial institution's failure to detect, even with the use of artificial intelligence, atypical transactions that differed from the client's profile, showing a deficiency in the duty of security and giving rise to restitution of the amounts.
excerpt: "7. Espera-se das instituições bancárias diligências suficientes para detectar e prevenir golpes, considerando que operações fraudulentas, em sua maioria, possuem um padrão de atipicidade, fogem ao perfil do correntista e podem ser averiguadas antes da sua confirmação mediante o emprego de dispositivos de tecnologia da informação e/ou inteligência artificial acessíveis aos bancos."

summary:
"Google permanently disabled a doctor's email account after identifying, through artificial intelligence, five files related to child sexual abuse, which were later reported to the NCMEC, denying full access to the stored content.
The Court considered the account deactivation to be legitimate based on the violation of the terms of use, but determined that the non-infringing personal files should be made available to the user, recognizing the platform's duty to distinguish illicit content with technical support and guarantee access to the remaining data."
excerpt:
"11. A ré esclarece que referidas declarações derivam dos relatórios elaborados e enviados pela Equipe de Segurança Infantil da Google LLC ao NCMEC com informações e dados obtidos por meio de tecnologia de inteligência artificial que identifica e classifica as imagens como potencialmente infringentes que posteriormente são avaliadas por revisores humanos.
12. Nesse contexto, verifica-se suficiente força probatória das declarações detalhadas emitidas pela Equipe de Segurança Infantil da Google LLC e pelo Centro Nacional para Crianças Desaparecidas e Exploradas (NCMEC), em especial por se tratar de conteúdo sensível e violador das leis de proteção às crianças e aos adolescentes.
13. Mostra-se legítima, portanto, a desativação unilateral da conta de e-mail do autor em razão da constatação de violação aos termos de uso e das políticas da empresa.
"

summary:
"The author filed a lawsuit seeking the reactivation of his registration as a driver on the 99 platform, alleging an error in the artificial intelligence in facial recognition that resulted in his dismissal.
The court understood that, despite the claim of an AI error, the unilateral termination was provided for in the contract."
excerpt:
"3. Conforme se nota dos termos de uso do motorista, as partes pactuaram a possibilidade de rescisão unilateral, por qualquer dos contratantes e o motorista parceiro tinha ciência de que a utilização do serviço pode ser cancelada, sem notificação prévia, em virtude da utilização de terceiros ou transferência de sua conta. 3.1. Do que consta nos autos, a inteligência artificial da requerida não reconheceu as fotos enviadas pelo autor como sendo da mesma pessoa constante no cadastro. 
"

summary:
"The plaintiff filed a lawsuit for damages after discovering, in its confidential laboratory results area, the undue inclusion of a genetic ancestry test that it had not requested.

The court acknowledged the laboratory's error, but highlighted that specific failures resulting from the use of artificial intelligence and computer systems, without any real impact on human dignity, should not be treated as necessarily giving rise to moral damages."
excerpt:
"2. O uso de inteligência artificial e outros sistemas informáticos trazem ganhos para a sociedade, que deve, por outro lado, ser tolerante com as contrapartidas inerentes à evolução. Não se deve julgar situações inocentes, sem nenhuma repercussão na esfera da dignidade humana, como se fosse o fim do mundo, transformando átimos de sensibilidade pessoal em fonte de indenização por dano moral. 
"

summary:
"The author's email account was deactivated by Microsoft after automated detection, via artificial intelligence, of a violation of the rules of use, resulting in the permanent deletion of the data.

The court recognized the technical impossibility of reactivation as just cause, highlighting that the use of AI to detect violative behaviors can lead to irreversible consequences, for which liability depends on proof of illegality."
excerpt: "2. A conta de email do Autor foi desativada após detectada, por meio da inteligência artificial, suposta contrariedade às regras de conduta do usuário, sendo crível que, nesse contexto, tenham sido apagados todos os arquivos armazenados naquele endereço eletrônico."

summary:
"The author was the victim of fraud committed by a third party who, posing as a bank manager, took out a loan in her name, and was only assisted by artificial intelligence when trying to resolve the problem.

The court recognized the failure to provide the service and the violation of the General Data Protection Law, highlighting that the automated service with AI, without any human support, aggravated the moral damage due to the financial institution's inertia in the face of the fraud."
excerpt:
"10. Danos morais. A sentença não merece reforma. Restou demonstrado o desgaste emocional que a parte autora sofreu, com a indiferença da parte ré, que não prestou nenhum atendimento para solução do problema. A parte autora não foi atendida por nenhum preposto da empresa, conseguindo apenas atendimento com inteligência artificial, através de ligação telefônica automática. Em se tratando de crime de estelionato, era dever da parte ré dar a atenção necessária para solução do problema, o que foi completamente ignorado por ela, porque estavam efetuando os descontos automáticos na folha de pagamento da parte autora, o que na sua visão estava tudo dentro da legalidade.
"

summary:
"The plaintiff filed a lawsuit alleging undue negative listing resulting from a charge related to a bank contract, the debt for which had already been renewed, claiming moral damages and double refund of the amounts paid.

The court acknowledged that the charge was excessive, but in good faith, and highlighted that inconsistencies resulting from the use of artificial intelligence and bank computerization do not constitute bad faith, as this is an exclusively human attribute, and it is not possible to apply the sanctions of art. 940 of the Civil Code in these cases."
excerpt: "12. As inconsistências do emprego de inteligência artificial e da informatização em geral não podem ser punidas com o rótulo da má-fé, atributo exclusivamente humano, ínsito a quem anota, naquela mencionada caderneta, uma compra que não foi feita ou uma dívida que já foi paga, para dobrar, fraudulentamente, o lucro no fim do mês."

summary: The court recognized the financial institution's failure to detect, even with the use of artificial intelligence, atypical transactions that differed from the client's profile, showing a deficiency in the duty of security and giving rise to restitution of the amounts.
excerpt: "Por outro lado, o banco recorrido quedou-se inerte, colacionando ao feito, apenas, sua contestação, não trazendo nenhuma prova do uso do cartão magnético ou senha pessoal do consumidor, na transação contestada. Sequer explica a inconsistência do sistema que não detectou gritante anomalia temporal. A inteligência artificial pode ser programada para criticar situações de extrema incoerência, como a presente."

caseName: J. Doe v. Iowa District Court for Polk County
summary:
In J. Doe v. Iowa District Court for Polk County, the plaintiff sought to expunge two parole violation reports that appeared as felony criminal cases in Iowa Courts Online, arguing they stemmed from an arrest that was later dismissed and expunged.
The Iowa Supreme Court denied expungement, holding that parole violation reports are administrative, not criminal, matters, and thus not eligible under the expungement statute, even though their online classification as criminal may mislead AI-driven background checks.
excerpt:
"Yet, the theory behind the expungement

statute is that appearances matter. Prospective employers, landlords, and the

like—or the artificial intelligence programs they are using—may not be willing to

drill down to the true facts.”

court: District of Columbia Court of Appeals
summary: In Ross v. United States, the D.C. Court of Appeals considered whether leaving a dog in a car on a 98°F day constituted animal cruelty, with AI tools like ChatGPT cited by both majority and dissent in arguments over what constitutes “common knowledge.”
excerpt:
"We, like the dissent, harbor doubts about whether ChatGPT is “a good proxy
for what is, and what isn’t, common knowledge.” Post at 37 n.4. But to the extent
the dissent relies on ChatGPT’s degree of certainty as to whether leaving a dog in a
hot car is harmful, we note that ChatGPT expresses similar certainty in its response
to the query, “How much would a pretty clean, operable 2002 Dodge Intrepid with
no significant dents or scratches have been worth in 2012?”:
             In 2012, a 2002 Dodge Intrepid in pretty clean, operable
             condition with no significant dents or scratches would
             have likely been worth between $3,000 and $5,000.
             The exact price would have depended on factors such as
             mileage, location, and the specific condition of the car
             (interior, mechanical health, etc.). For instance, a lower-
             mileage model with a well-maintained engine could have
             been closer to the higher end of that range, while a higher-
             mileage model might have been valued closer to the lower
             end. Generally, as a mid-size sedan from 2002, it would
             not have been fetching a premium price by 2012, but it still
             had decent value as an affordable used car.
Note that $3,000 (ChatGPT’s minimum price) is significantly above the $1,000
threshold at issue in Long. ChatGPT’s analysis, therefore, does not correspond to at
least one of our sufficiency decisions.
“

caseName: How W. Byrd v. The Villages of Woodland Springs Homeowners Association, Inc.
summary: Inexistent case law was presented to the Court.
excerpt:
"In the statement-of-the-case section of his brief, Byrd clarified, without
citation, that Arcadia is an opinion from the United States Supreme Court. Cf. Tex. R.
App. P. 38.1(d) (stating that the brief must state concisely the nature of the case, the
course of proceedings, and the trial court’s disposition). Neither party has provided us
with guidance to identify the Arcadia opinion to which Byrd referred, and we have
been unable to identify it. Cf. Tex. R. App. 38.1(k)(2) (stating that a brief’s appendix
may contain optional content such as “copies or excerpts of relevant court opinions”).
Further, in his index of authorities, Byrd cites the “Texas Property Code Section 42-
USC 51, 52, 209” and the “Texas Civil Properties and Rental Codes.” We cannot tell
from Byrd’s brief if he used ChatGPT or another artificial intelligence (AI) source to
attempt to develop his legal citations. See David T. Laton, A Cautionary Tale of AI As A
Research Tool for Lawyers, Prac. Law. 42, 43 (2024) (“ChatGPT currently lacks the ability
to produce reliable and accurate results when given a legal query.”).”

court: Appellate Division of the Supreme Court of the State of New York
caseName: Matter of Philadelphia Ins. Indem. Co. v. Kendall
summary: The court held that emails can satisfy signature requirements under CPLR 2104 without a retyped name, and noted that while email is generally presumed authentic, this presumption can be rebutted if the message was allegedly sent by a hacker, artificial intelligence, or another unauthorized source.
excerpt:
"First, there may be issues of authentication. Email accounts can be hacked. An email from an attorney's account is presumed to be authentic, but that is a rebuttable presumption. Just as a party may attack a hardcopy settlement offer or acceptance as a forgery, a party that claims an email was the product of a hacker (or of artificial intelligence, or of some other source) may rebut its authenticity.
“

court: District Court for the District of Columbia
summary:
The U.S. State Department used an AI-powered “Catch and Revoke” program to cancel visas of foreign students, including Plaintiff Ahwar Sultan, allegedly for supporting designated terrorist groups, leading to the termination of his SEVIS record without notice.
The court found that relying on AI-based visa revocation without individualized due process likely violated agency rules and the Fifth Amendment, and ordered Sultan’s SEVIS record temporarily reinstated.
excerpt:
". On March 6, 2025, the State Department confirmed that: (1) it was

planning to review internal databases to see whether any visa holders were arrested and had not

been subjected to immigration enforcement; id. ¶ 131, and (2) it would enact the “Catch and

Revoke” program, an artificial intelligence effort to “cancel the visas of foreign nationals who

appear to support Hamas or other designated terror groups (…) As a result, Sultan is in a catch-22

situation—he cannot attend school or work because his SEVIS record is terminated; nor does he

know whether he should leave the United States immediately or risk being subject to removal
                                            Page 7 of 11
proceedings, because Defendants refuse to provide him with the necessary information. Sultan

must therefore wait in legal limbo, at possible risk of detention, until Defendants decide whether

and how he should be removed.”

court: District Court for the Northern District of Illinois
caseName: Vehicle Intelligence & Safety LLC v. Mercedes-Benz USA, LLC
summary:
Vehicle Intelligence & Safety LLC sued Mercedes-Benz for patent infringement, claiming that the “ATTENTION ASSIST” system infringed a patent using expert systems—an early form of AI—to detect driver impairment.
The court held the patent invalid under § 101, finding it covered an abstract idea—impairment detection using conventional expert systems—without adding any inventive concept beyond generic computer implementation.
excerpt:
"Abstract ideas are excluded from eligibility based on the concern that monopolization of the basic tools of scientific and technological work could impede innovation more than promote it. Abstract ideas referred to in Alice Corp., 134 S.Ct. at 2350, include: fundamental economic practices instructing how to hedge a risk, citing Bilski 561 U.S. at 599, 130 S.Ct. 3218; an algorithm code for converting binary-coded numerals to pure binary form, citing Gottschalk v. Benson, 409 U.S. 63, 67, 93 S.Ct. 253, 34 L.Ed.2d 273 (1972); and a mathematical formula for computing alarm limits in a catalytic conversion process, citing Parker v. Flook, 437 U.S. 584, 594-595, 98 S.Ct. 2522, 57 L.Ed.2d 451 (1978).
Limitations that may be enough to qualify as significantly more or to embody an *888inventive concept were said to be improvements to another technology or technical field or improvements to the functioning of a computer. Alice Corp., 134 S.Ct. at 2359-60. However, requiring no more than a generic computer to perform generic computer functions that are well-understood activities previously know to the computer industry would not be sufficient. Id. at 2359 (citing Mayo, 132 S.Ct. at 1297, 1301).
The claims in this case broadly relate to the concept of testing operators of any kind of moving equipment for any kind of physical or mental impairment.”

caseName: CreateAI Holdings Inv. F/K/A TuSimple Holdings, Inc. v. Bot Auto TX Inc.
summary: CreateAI sued Bot Auto for allegedly misappropriating trade secrets related to autonomous vehicle AI systems, including sensor suites, decision-making, and safety technologies. Bot Auto argues on appeal that CreateAI failed to justify a temporary injunction under TUTSA because it did not clearly identify any protectable AI-related trade secrets or show that Bot Auto accessed or used them.

In her concurring opinion, Chief Justice Timmer raised concerns about the Court’s use of corpus linguistics without adversarial testing, warning that the method’s increasing integration with artificial intelligence may amplify problems
excerpt:
"¶46           This special concurrence is not the place to thoroughly
analyze if and how corpus linguistics should be used to interpret legal texts.
I am not an expert in linguistics, and I am unwilling to engage in scientific
research without input from parties affected by the results. See State v.
Rasabout, 356 P.3d 1258, 1264–66 ¶¶ 16–21 (Utah 2015) (criticizing sua
sponte corpus linguistics research as unfair to parties and outside judicial
expertise). Instead, I urge parties in future cases to examine the utility of
corpus linguistics and advise this Court about if and how corpus linguistics
should be used. This analysis may become particularly imperative as
corpus linguistics interacts with artificial intelligence. See Henderson, supra
¶ 44, at 132 (warning that problems with corpus linguistics are likely to
increase with the corresponding use of large language models “as meaning
can include the arbitrary references of annotators or model creators”).
“

court: Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit
summary:
In United States v. Hay, the Tenth Circuit upheld the use of a motion-activated pole camera that recorded a veteran’s home for 68 days as part of a fraud investigation, rejecting the claim that it violated the Fourth Amendment.
The court found that the surveillance did not constitute a “search” because the camera only captured what was visible to the public from the street, and thus did not intrude upon any reasonable expectation of privacy, distinguishing it from Carpenter and affirming that conventional surveillance tools like cameras remain constitutionally permissible, including because expectations of privacy are being reduced by the advances of technologies such as AI.
excerpt:
"Artificial intelligence software accelerates facial

  identification and pattern recognition to a previously unimaginable degree. As video

  cameras proliferate throughout society, regrettably, the reasonable expectation of

  privacy from filming is diminished.”

summary:
In United States v. Shipp, the government obtained 21,000 pages of data from a defendant’s Facebook account using a broad warrant, which included metadata, private messages, and app activity, some of which involved AI-driven data collection and profiling.
The court noted that Facebook’s aggregation and analysis of user data—potentially using artificial intelligence to infer behavior and identity—raises significant Fourth Amendment concerns due to the platform’s scope and invasiveness, but ultimately upheld the warrant under the good-faith exception.
excerpt:
"m This threat is further elevated in a search of Facebook data because, perhaps more than any other location-including a residence, a computer hard drive, or a car-Facebook provides a single window through which almost every detail of a person's life is visible.5 Indeed, Facebook is designed to replicate, record, and facilitate personal, familial, social, professional, and financial activity and networks. Users not only voluntarily entrust information concerning just about every aspect of their lives to the service, but Facebook also proactively collects and aggregates information about its users and non-users in ways that we are only just beginning to understand. See, e.g., Josh Constine, Facebook's new Study app pays adults for data after teen scandal, TECHCRUNCH , June 11, 2019, https://techcrunch.com/2019/06/11/study-from-facebook/ (describing various apps Facebook has built and launched that, once installed, send all the data on a person's phone to Facebook); Sarah Frier and Todd Shields, Zuckerberg Says Facebook Collects Internet Data on Non-Users, BLOOMBERG , Apr. 11, 2018, https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-04-11/zuckerberg-says-facebook-collects-internet-data-on-non-users (describing Facebook's practice of tracking nonusers' internet activity); Natasha Singer, What You Don't Know About How Facebook Uses Your Data, N.Y. TIMES , Apr. 11, 2018, https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/11/technology/facebook-privacy-hearings.html (explaining that Facebook tracks users and non-users, collects biometric facial data, and "can learn almost anything about you by using artificial intelligence to analyze your behavior"). (See also Aff. ¶ 27 (explaining that "Facebook also provides its users with access to thousands of other applications ('apps') on the Facebook platform")). Particularly troubling, information stored in non-Facebook applications may come to constitute part of a user's "Facebook account"-and thus be subject to broad searches-by virtue of corporate decisions, such as mergers and integrations, without the act or awareness of any particular user. See Alex Hern, EU data watchdog raises concerns over Facebook integration, THE GUARDIAN , Jan. 28, 2019, https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/jan/28/eu-data-watchdog-raises-concerns-facebook-integration (discussing privacy concerns arising from Facebook's plans to merge three messaging networks that it owns-Facebook Messenger, WhatsApp, and Instagram). It is thus hard to imagine many searches more invasive than a search of all the data associated with a Facebook account. Cf. Riley, 573 U.S. at 394, 134 S.Ct. 2473 ("The sum of an individual's private life can be reconstructed through a thousand photographs labeled with dates, locations, and descriptions.").
The Second Circuit has cautioned that "[b]ecause of the nature of digital storage, it is not always feasible to 'extract and segregate responsive data from non-responsive data.' “"

court: District Court of  Appeal of Florida
caseName: RLG, A juvenile v. The State of Florida
summary: The court declined to decide whether such GPS data qualifies as non-hearsay “machine statements” due to the lack of evidence about how the data was produced, but acknowledged that future AI-generated evidence may require rethinking hearsay rules, as algorithms, not humans, are increasingly the source of accusatory information.
excerpt:
"The legal basis for the State’s theory is the growing trend in the law to

recognize that evidence of information from new technologies like GPS

location, DNA matches, facial recognition, and chromatography (used to

detect chemicals in samples) is often generated without human input. As

noted by several commentors, in the brave new world of artificial intelligence,

the finger of accusation is often pointed, not by a human being, but by an
algorithm”

summary: The Court noted how the rules of evidence will have to adapt in face of new technologies, including artificial intelligence.
excerpt:
"               We are mindful that, as the world continuously confronts constantly
          evolving and more sophisticated technology, such as artificial intelligence,
          the rules of evidence may need to adapt. Under the facts and circumstances
          of the present case, however, we conclude that our rules of evidence provide
          the appropriate framework for the authentication of the Twitter posts and
          that the low threshold for authentication was met.
“

court: Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit
caseName: Citizens Insurance Company of America v. Wynndalco Enterprises, LLC
summary:
Citizens Insurance refused to defend Wynndalco in lawsuits alleging it violated Illinois’ Biometric Information Privacy Act (BIPA) by distributing access to Clearview AI’s facial recognition database containing scraped biometric data.
The court held Citizens must defend Wynndalco because the insurance policy’s exclusion clause was too ambiguous, especially regarding AI-generated biometric privacy harms, and did not clearly bar coverage for BIPA violations.
excerpt:
"    The litigation that has given rise to this coverage dispute
stems from a massive database of facial-image scans assem-
bled by Clearview AI, an artificial intelligence firm that spe-
cializes in facial recognition software. We accept as true the
following factual allegations gleaned from the two com-
plaints filed against Wynndalco.
    Clearview AI allegedly has extracted or “scraped” in ex-
cess of three billion photographs of individuals from online
social media, content-sharing, and digital payment platforms
(including Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, TikTok, Snapchat,
YouTube, Google Photos, LinkedIn, and Venmo); converted
those images into biometric facial recognition identifiers us-
ing proprietary algorithms; collected the original images and
their biometric counterparts into its database; and paired
those images with information as to where those images were
found on the Internet. Clearview AI has also created a facial
recognition application or “app” that allows a user to identify
an individual by uploading a photograph of that person to the
app. The app then allows the user to see other photographs of
4                                                     No. 22-2313

that same person on the media platforms or websites where
they appear, along with the identifying information (includ-
ing their name, address, and other personal information) as-
sociated with that individual. Thus, a user could take a pho-
tograph of a stranger on the street and upload the image to
the app, which converts the photograph into a biometric facial
scan, and (assuming the individual’s photos and information
are in Clearview AI’s database), determine who that person
is, and access any number of additional photographs of and
associated content (tweets, Facebook and Instagram posts,
YouTube and TikTok videos, LinkedIn profiles, etc.) created
by and about that individual. Clearview AI marketed the app
to law enforcement agencies, among others. See Kashmir Hill,
The Secretive Company That Might End Privacy As We Know It,
NEW YORK TIMES (Jan. 18, 2020), available at https://www.ny-
times.com/2020/01/18/technology/clearview-privacy-facial-
recognition.html?.
   The Chicago Police Department, through its purchasing
agent CDW-Government, gained access to the Clearview AI
database and its facial-identification app by means of a two-
year contract between CDW-Government and Wynndalco.
“

court: Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit
caseName: Eric K. Brooks v. D Miller
summary: The Court noted how the rules of evidence will have to adapt in face of new technologies, including artificial intelligence.
excerpt:
"In a world of artificial intelligence, video and picture editing
        software, and video and image generators—to only name a few—
        we must “tread carefully . . . to ensure that we do not ‘embarrass
        the future’” when assessing video footage like the dash-cam record-
        ing in this case.”

summary: The Court noted how the rules of evidence will have to adapt in face of new technologies, including artificial intelligence.
excerpt:
"As this Court observed over 35 years ago, “the potentially limitless application of
computer technology to evidentiary questions will continually require legal adaptation.” Penny
v. Commonwealth, 6 Va. App. 494, 499 (1988). As artificial intelligence progresses, battles over
the accuracy of computer images and manipulation of “deepfakes” can be expected to intensify.
See generally Paul W. Grimm et al., Artificial Intelligence as Evidence, 19 Nw. J. Tech. & Intell.
Prop. 9 (2021). No such issues were raised here.”

summary:
During the COVID-19 pandemic, Westtoer (a public tourism body in Belgium) used AI-powered intelligent cameras in public spaces to count passers-by.
The Belgian DPA found no GDPR violation regarding the use of these AI cameras, as the system was designed with privacy by design and default, including real-time anonymization, but issued a reprimand for non-compliant cookie consent mechanisms and insufficient transparency in the privacy policy.
excerpt:
" Sur la base de ce qui précède, il apparaît que les images des caméras en question sont
presque immédiatement anonymisées et que l'identification des passants filmés est rendue
impossible.
91. La Chambre Contentieuse estime que ceci répond aux exigences de l'article 25.1 du RGPD et
du considérant 78 du RGPD ainsi qu'au principe de minimisation des données repris à l'article
5.1 c) du RGPD, auquel il est également fait référence par les premières dispositions citées.
Alors que l'article 25.1 du RGPD exige uniquement la pseudonymisation, les données à
caractère personnel en question sont anonymisées de façon irréversible.
92. Grâce à cette anonymisation quasiment immédiate, seules sont en effet traitées les données
à caractère personnel qui sont "pertinentes " et "limitées à ce qui est nécessaire au regard
des finalités pour lesquelles elles sont traitées " et celles-ci sont ensuite converties en données
de comptage anonymes ainsi qu'en images brouillées.”

summary:
Budapest Bank used AI to analyze customer service call recordings for emotional profiling and automated decision-making.
The Hungarian DPA found this AI-based processing lacked a valid legal basis, failed the balancing of interests test, and did not provide sufficient safeguards or inform data subjects, leading to a €700,000 fine.

IDA Forsikring used AI-powered speech recognition to transcribe and analyze customer service calls for quality assurance and service improvement, based on a dictionary of positive and negative words developed from 30 million calls.
The Danish DPA found that while the AI analysis itself was lawful and not considered profiling, the company’s method of obtaining consent for call recording and AI processing lacked the required granularity and thus did not meet GDPR standards.

caseName:
Binding Decision 4/2022 on the dispute submitted by the
Irish SA on Meta Platforms Ireland Limited and its Instagram
service (Art. 65 GDPR)
summary:
Meta IE was accused of unlawfully processing Instagram users’ personal data for behavioural advertising by claiming it was necessary for contract performance, without obtaining valid consent under the GDPR.

The EDPB found that behavioural advertising is not essential to the Instagram contract, that Meta could not rely on Article 6(1)(b) GDPR, and that the company’s practices, especially its take-it-or-leave-it model and bundled consent, violated GDPR principles, requiring corrective measures and higher fines.

A data subject objected to their bank using transaction data to train models for a personalised discount system, arguing this repurposing required consent and was unrelated to the original transaction purpose.
The Belgian DPA held that training models for personalised discounts, when identifiers are removed, data is not shared or reused to target the user without consent, and the user can object, constitutes a legitimate interest and minimally impactful processing, making it lawful under Article 6(1)(f) GDPR.

The Greek Ministry of Migration and Asylum deployed surveillance systems using CCTV, drones, and AI-based behavioral analytics in asylum centers, including biometric data processing, without adequate legal basis or transparency.
The Greek DPA found violations of the GDPR due to unlawful processing of sensitive data, insufficient legal justification for biometric and AI-based surveillance, incomplete data protection impact assessments, and failure to ensure transparency and accountability, resulting in a €175,000 fine and a 3-month compliance order.

The City of Copenhagen planned to implement an AI tool to predict which citizens might benefit from rehabilitation, using sensitive health and social data.
The Danish DPA found that the AI tool’s operation lacked a sufficiently clear and specific legal basis under national law, making it incompatible with Article 6(3) GDPR requirements for high-risk, decision-support AI processing by public authorities.

In 2020, members of the Finnish Central Criminal Police used Clearview AI’s facial recognition tool during a free trial to identify potential child abuse victims, processing biometric data without proper oversight or legal basis.
The Finnish DPA found this use violated the national Criminal Data Protection Act because the police conducted intrusive biometric data processing without prior authorization, safeguards, or transparency, and ordered corrective measures including deletion requests and data subject notification.

The case concerned an Italian association that calculated “reputation ratings” for individuals and legal entities through an algorithm. The Italian DPA (Garante) had previously prohibited the processing under the Italian Privacy Code, citing lack of transparency and valid consent. The association challenged this prohibition, claiming it had obtained proper consent, disclosed the algorithmic method, and complied with legal obligations.
The Italian Supreme Court reversed the lower court’s ruling and found that the association had lawfully obtained consent under Article 7 GDPR and Article 13 of the Italian Privacy Code. The Court clarified that informed consent does not require technical mastery of the algorithm by the data subject. Instead, consent is valid if the algorithmic logic, purposes, and variables used are explained in an intelligible, unambiguous manner, sufficient for a non-technical user to understand the essence of the processing. The Court found that the association provided this level of transparency, including public documentation and a patent that described the algorithm’s operation. Therefore, the data subjects gave valid, informed consent.

The Belgian DPA investigated IAB Europe’s Transparency and Consent Framework (TCF), used in Real-Time Bidding (RTB) systems, for GDPR violations involving the processing and dissemination of users’ preferences and personal data.
The DPA held that IAB Europe acted as a (joint) data controller by defining essential means and purposes of processing via the TCF, including algorithmic profiling and consent capture mechanisms, without a valid legal basis, sufficient transparency, or adequate technical safeguards, violating Articles 5, 6, 7, 25, and 32 GDPR.

The applicant challenged the refusal of his Canadian visa, arguing that the immigration officer improperly relied on Chinook AI software to make the decision.
The Court rejected this argument, finding no evidence that Chinook made or dictated the decision and reiterating established precedent that using Chinook does not, on its own, breach procedural fairness or reasonableness standards.
excerpt: "In addition, as the Respondent points out, the Paper does not support the Applicant’s assertion that the Officer delegated their decision-making responsibility to Chinook. If anything, the Paper expressly confirms that ““[t]here are no auto-refusals.”

summary:
In Droit de la famille — 2541, the Quebec Superior Court ruled on divorce and asset division between a wife and her incarcerated husband, who also submitted unsupported claims citing AI-generated medical information.
The Court rejected the husband’s AI-sourced evidence as medically unsubstantiated and not credible, reaffirming that legal decisions, especially those regarding spousal support, must be based on admissible, expert-backed evidence, not information from artificial intelligence platforms
excerpt: "immediately upon receipt of a bona fide a medical report indicating the necessity of such surgery, but he has failed to provide any credible evidence to substantiate same. Rather, the Husband has provided the Court with a medical scan of his heart which clearly the Court is not qualified to interpret. He also provided the Court with information from an artificial intelligence site.    The Court has no knowledge if the proposed medical intervention would be of benefit to the Husband or place him at significant risk.”

summary: Inexistent case law was presented to the Court.
excerpt:
".   The Geismayrs’ submissions reference ten decisions where they say courts ruled that a strata could not force the removal of strata lot alterations. These cases have the parties’ names and the years published, but no legal citation. Nine of these cases do not exist. The remaining case, “The Owners, Strata Plan LMS 2768 v. Jordison (2013)”, has three court decisions published in 2013, however, none of these are related to unauthorized alterations. The Geismayrs listed the source of these cases as a “Conversation with Copilot” which is an artificial intelligence chatbot. I find it likely that these cases are “hallucinations” where artificial intelligence generates false or misleading results.

26.   The state of the law is very different than what Copilot reported.”

summary: Inexistent case law was presented to the Court.
excerpt:
". Turning to an amount, AQ did not provide much of an explanation or justification for 
her $25,000 claim. Under the CRT’s rules, the basis for compensation is for AQ’s 
time. Given that, I find it relevant that AQ used artificial intelligence to create some, 
7 
and maybe most, of her submissions. These submissions bear the two hallmarks of 
artificially created submissions: they are very long and repetitive, and (more 
tellingly) they confidently cite irrelevant rules, incorrect sections of statutes, and 
court cases that are either about something completely different from what the 
submissions assert or do not exist at all.  
23. I provide the following examples. AQ refers to CRT rule 7 and CRTA section 50(2) 
as authority for awarding special costs. CRT rule 7 has nothing to do with awarding 
costs, and there is no section 50(2) in the CRTA. She relies on Doucet-Boudreau v. 
Nova Scotia (Minister of Education), 2003 SCC 62 to make a point about the harm 
of digitally manipulated content when the case is actually about language rights. 
She also cites cases Jordan v. Law Society of British Columbia, 2018 BCCA 181, 
and West Coast Environmental Law Association v. British Columbia (Ministry of 
Forests, Lands and Natural Resource Operations), 2019 BCSC 1935, which do not 
exist. The citation of plausible-looking but non-existent cases, in particular, is similar 
to other cases involving artificial intelligence-generated submissions.”

summary: Inexistent case law was presented to the Court.
excerpt: "Mr. Oak has provided detailed submissions with numerous statutory and legal references. I presume that Mr. Oak’s submissions were partly or mostly drafted by an Artificial Intelligence (AI) platform. I say this because if the submissions were Mr. Oak’s personal work product, he would have intentionally misled the CRT with false statutes and cases. The submissions quote 5 sections of the Employment Standards Act (ESA) and all of them are incorrectly quoted. Four of the cases relied upon do not stand for the proposition described in the submission. One of the cases does not exist at all. All 5 of these cases are critical to Mr. Oak’s argument.”

caseName: Simpson v. Hung Long Enterprises Inc
summary: Inexistent case law was presented to the Court.
excerpt:
"25.   I agree with Hung Long that there are two extraordinary circumstances here that justify compensation for its time. The first is Ms. Simpson’s use of artificial intelligence. It takes little time to have a large language model create lengthy submissions with many case citations. It takes considerably more effort for the other party to wade through those submissions to determine which cases are real, and for those that are, whether they actually say what Ms. Simpson purported they did. Hung Long’s owner clearly struggled to understand Ms. Simpson’s submissions, and his legal research to try to understand them was an utter waste of his time. I reiterate my point above that Ms. Simpson’s submissions cited a non-existent case in support of a legal position that is the precise opposite of the existing law. This underscores the impact on Hung Long. How can a self-represented party respond to a seemingly convincing legal argument that is based on a case it is impossible to find?

26.   I am mindful that Ms. Simpson is not a lawyer and that legal research is challenging. That said, she is responsible for the information she provides the CRT. I find it manifestly unfair that the burden of Ms. Simpson’s use of artificial intelligence should fall to Hung Long’s owner, who tried his best to understand submissions that were not capable of being understood. While I accept that Ms. Simpson did not knowingly provide fake cases or misleading submissions, she was reckless about their accuracy. I note that the BC Supreme Court required a lawyer to personally compensate another lawyer for their wasted time from trying to find non-existent cases from artificially generated submissions.[4] While Ms. Simpson does not have the same professional obligations that a lawyer has, she still has an obligation as a CRT participant not to provide misleading information.”

summary: Inexistent case law was presented to the Court.
excerpt:
"[8]         I asked Ms. Lee if her factum was prepared by artificial intelligence - like ChatGPT.  She told me that her office does not usually do so but that she would have to check with her clerk. Ms. Lee was unable to provide me with citations to the cases cited in her factum or to provide me with copies of the cases from the printed papers she was using to make her submissions.

“

summary: Inexistent case law was presented to the Court.

The claimant generated an image using a text-to-image AI model with a simple prompt and, after a Prague law firm used it without consent, sued to confirm authorship and stop its use.
The Court held that, since only a natural person can be an author under Czech law and the claimant failed to prove that his specific prompt directly produced the image, AI-generated output is not a copyrightable work and thus the claim must be dismissed.

In a 2024 electoral case, the Ceará Regional Electoral Court rejected a motion for clarification (embargos de declaração) filed against a prior ruling that had overturned a fine for AI use in a humorous campaign piece deemed non-misleading.
excerpt:
"2. A questão em discussão consiste em apreciar se o Acórdão embargado incorreu em erro material ao afastar a aplicação de multa por uso indevido de Inteligência Artificial, ao fundamento de que o conteúdo divulgado se tratava de peça humorística sem potencial de induzir o eleitorado a erro. 
III. RAZÕES DE DECIDIR 
3. Os embargos de declaração são cabíveis apenas nas hipóteses de omissão, obscuridade, contradição ou erro material, nos termos do art. 1.022 do Código de Processo Civil, aplicado ao processo eleitoral por força do art. 275 do Código Eleitoral. 
4. O inconformismo com a tese jurídica firmada pelo Acórdão não se confunde com erro material, que deve decorrer de equívoco objetivo e manifesto, como troca de nomes, datas, erros de digitação ou de cálculo. 5. O voto embargado enfrentou a matéria apontada como viciada, ainda que em sentido desfavorável ao embargante, para afastar a sanção com base em fundamentos que não constituem erro evidente, mas interpretação jurídica sobre o alcance da vedação ao uso de Inteligência Artificial em campanhas. 
“

summary:
An electoral appeal challenged a lower court decision that dismissed a complaint alleging irregular campaign propaganda involving a supposed deep fake video circulated via Instagram and WhatsApp during the 2024 elections.

The Court found the video was satirical, not a deep fake using AI to deceive, and concluded it neither spread manifestly false information nor seriously harmed the candidate; moreover, consensual messages in WhatsApp groups do not constitute electoral propaganda under TSE regulations, warranting dismissal of the appeal.
excerpt:
"II. QUESTÃO EM DISCUSSÃO
O cerne da questão consiste em saber em que consiste a mensagem com deep fake e se mensagens veiculadas no Instagram e em grupo de WhatsApp consistem em propaganda eleitoral irregular.
III. RAZÕES DE DECIDIR
Deep fake consiste em técnica que utiliza recursos de inteligência artificial para substituir rostos e imagens em vídeos. Não é o caso dos autos. Vídeo com montagem e conteúdo de sátira. Uso do humor e da ironia para tecer críticas e ridicularizar aspectos da sociedade, sem veiculação de fato manifestamente inverídico ou de ofensa grave ao candidato a atrair a intervenção deste Judiciário Eleitoral, que deve ser mínima (art. 5º, 3º, da Resolução nº 23.735/2024/TSE).
“

summary: The case discusses content created by AI in electoral contexts.
excerpt:
"ELEIÇÕES 2024. RECURSO ELEITORAL. REPRESENTAÇÃO POR PROPAGANDA ELEITORAL IRREGULAR. INTERNET. POSTAGEM NO INSTAGRAM. VÍDEO ORIGINAL ADULTERADO. MENSAGEM DISTORCIDA E DESINFORMATIVA. EMPREGO DE INTELIGÊNCIA ARTIFICIAL. MANUTENÇÃO DA MULTA EM PATAMAR MÉDIO. NÃO PROVIMENTO. 
1. Sentença que condenou candidatos a Prefeito e Vice, bem como a coligação da chapa, por veiculação nas redes sociais de propaganda eleitoral irregular, consubstanciada em vídeo editado, com emprego de inteligência artificial e propagação de desinformação. 
"

summary: The case discusses content created by AI in electoral contexts.
excerpt:
"ELEIÇÕES 2024. RECURSO. AIJE. IMPROCEDÊNCIA NA ORIGEM. ALEGAÇÃO DE USO INDEVIDO DOS MEIOS DE COMUNICAÇÃO. PRELIMINAR DE CERCEAMENTO AO DIREITO DE DEFESA DECORRENTE DO INDEFERIMENTO DE PROVA TESTEMUNHAL. REJEIÇÃO. MÉRITO. PUBLICAÇÃO ISOLADA, DEFLAGRADA NO PERFIL PARTICULAR DE CANDIDATA À VEREANÇA NÃO ELEITA, CONTENDO PROPAGANDA POSITIVA ENVOLVENDO RECURSOS DE INTELIGÊNCIA ARTIFICIAL. SUPOSTA VIOLAÇÃO AOS ARTS. 22 DA LC Nº 64/90, 9º–B E 9º–C, §§ 1º E 2º DA RES. TSE Nº 23.610/2019. AUSÊNCIA DE GRAVIDADE IMPUTÁVEL À CONDUTA. INEXISTÊNCIA DE PROCEDER ABUSIVO. DESPROVIMENTO. MANUTENÇÃO DA SENTENÇA HOSTILIZADA.
“

summary: The case discusses content created by AI in electoral contexts.
excerpt:
"1. Foi oferecida representação com fundamento na realização de propaganda eleitoral negativa em perfil anônimo na internet, com o uso de inteligência artificial, que afetaria a legitimidade do pleito. 
2. A representação foi julgada improcedente tendo em vista a identificação da pessoa responsável pelo perfil bem como por não haver, nas postagens, fatos ofensivos ou difamatórios à imagem ou à honra da candidata. 
II. Questão em discussão 
3. A controvérsia consiste em verificar se a postagem, realizada em perfil do Instagram, de conteúdo produzido via Chat GPT, cuja responsável foi identificada, pode ser considerada propaganda eleitoral negativa que macule a imagem e a honra de candidata ao pleito. 
III. Razões de decidir 
4. Não se identificando conteúdo ofensivo ou difamatório nas postagens, tampouco a intenção de promover desrespeito e violência política contra mulher, não há que se falar em propaganda eleitoral negativa, privilegiando–se a liberdade de expressão e o direito à informação. 
“

summary: The case discusses content created by AI in electoral contexts.
excerpt:
"3. A legislação eleitoral veda a utilização de deep fake para criar, substituir ou alterar imagem ou voz com potencial de influenciar o eleitorado (art. 9º–C, § 1º, da Resolução TSE nº 23.610/2019). Contudo, a jurisprudência tem se posicionado no sentido de que manipulação grosseira ou de fácil percepção não caracteriza deep fake apta a prejudicar ou favorecer candidaturas (TRE/RS, REl 060006411/RS; TRE/SP, REl 060006746/SP). 
4. No caso concreto, o vídeo adversado revelava montagem humorística de personalidades internacionais em apoio ao recorrente, então candidato a Prefeito, sem aparência de veracidade. O eleitor médio não poderia ser induzido a erro, pois a peça possuía características evidentes de brincadeira, inserindo–se no contexto dos chamados memes da internet.

summary: The case discusses content created by AI in electoral contexts.
excerpt:
"A ausência de juntada aos autos do conteúdo publicitário objeto da demanda, elemento essencial para o desate da causa, impede a verificação da alegada ilicitude, levando à extinção do processo sem resolução de mérito. O autor da representação, ao requerer a exclusão do conteúdo impugnado, deveria ter zelado pela preservação da prova para exame futuro, especialmente considerando a alegação de uso de deep fake e inteligência artificial.
 IV. DISPOSITIVO E TESE 
Extinção do processo sem resolução de mérito. 
Tese de julgamento: 
A ausência nos autos do conteúdo impugnado por suposta propaganda eleitoral irregular, especialmente quando alegado uso de deep fake e inteligência artificial, impede a verificação da ilicitude e leva à extinção do processo sem resolução de mérito.”

ARTIGO 9º–B DA RESOLUÇÃO TSE Nº 23.610 E 57–D DA LEI N° 9.504/97. AUSÊNCIA DE PROVA DA MANIPULAÇÃO E DA FALSIDADE DAS INFORMAÇÕES. NÃO COMPROVAÇÃO DO DISPARO EM MASSA. summary: The case discusses content supposedly created by AI in electoral contexts.
excerpt:
"O vídeo compartilhado não foi criado por inteligência artificial, mas consiste em uma montagem editada a partir do curta-metragem de animação "Save Ralph", com inserção de imagens e referências ao candidato criticado.

A veiculação do conteúdo ocorreu em grupo privado de WhatsApp, caracterizando-se como comunicação interpessoal.

Apesar das críticas ácidas ao candidato, o conteúdo compartilhado enquadra-se no âmbito da liberdade de expressão e do debate político, não configurando propaganda eleitoral irregular, nos termos da legislação aplicável.

IV. DISPOSITIVO E TESE

Recurso provido, para julgar improcedente o pedido contido na petição inicial.

Tese de julgamento: 1. O compartilhamento de vídeo editado contendo críticas a candidato, em grupo privado de WhatsApp, sem uso de inteligência artificial, não configura propaganda eleitoral irregular passível de multa, nos termos do art. 57-B, § 5º, da Lei nº 9.504/97 e do art. 9º-C da Resolução TSE nº 23.610/2019, estando protegido pela liberdade de expressão.
"

summary: The case discusses content created by AI in electoral contexts.

Tese de julgamento: “A veiculação de conteúdo crítico com uso de deepfake, no contexto político, sem pedido explícito de não voto, sem ofensa manifesta à honra ou imagem e sem divulgação de fato sabidamente inverídico, não caracteriza propaganda eleitoral antecipada negativa, estando amparada pela liberdade de expressão.”

A liberdade de expressão, garantida pelo art. 5º, IV, da Constituição Federal, não é absoluta, devendo respeitar outros direitos fundamentais, como a honra e a imagem (art. 5º, X, CF). 7. A Resolução TSE nº 23.610/2019, alterada pela Resolução TSE nº 23.732/2024, veda expressamente a utilização de conteúdos manipulados ou sabidamente inverídicos na propaganda eleitoral, conforme previsto nos arts. 9–A e 9–C. 8. O conteúdo divulgado pelo recorrente utilizou inteligência artificial para produzir mensagem sabidamente inverídica, atentando contra a honra dos candidatos adversários e ultrapassando os limites do debate político legítimo. 9. A jurisprudência do TSE tem reiterado que a divulgação de fake news desequilibra a disputa eleitoral e prejudica a integridade do pleito, legitimando a imposição de sanções previstas na legislação eleitoral, como no art. 57–D da Lei nº 9.504/1997. 11. A class action was brought against the Australian government over the Robodebt system, an AI-assisted automated debt recovery program that used income averaging based on tax data to identify and collect alleged overpayments of social security benefits.

Reasoning: The court found that the AI system unlawfully generated debts by assuming steady income where none existed, causing financial and emotional harm, and approved a settlement acknowledging the illegality of the practice and compensating affected individuals.A class action was brought against the Australian government over the Robodebt system, an AI-assisted automated debt recovery program that used income averaging based on tax data to identify and collect alleged overpayments of social security benefits.
The court found that the AI system unlawfully generated debts by assuming steady income where none existed, causing financial and emotional harm, and approved a settlement acknowledging the illegality of the practice and compensating affected individuals.

A tech firm (Reface Technologies) sued an IT company (Business-Analytica) for unauthorized commercial use of a deepfake video featuring actor Keanu Reeves. The deepfake video had been created by a media studio for Reface, which owned exclusive rights. Business-Analytica argued that no copyright subsisted in the video since it was produced with AI (face-swapping deepfake technology). The Moscow court disagreed – ruling that AI was merely a tool in the editing process, not a substitute for human creativity, and that the video was a protected work authored by the humans who scripted, filmed and produced it. The court awarded Reface 500,000 RUB in damages. The judgment was upheld on appeal and finally confirmed by the IP Court, which in August 2024 rejected the defendant’s cassation appeal

Lawyer Alyona Popova and politician Vladimir Milov sued Moscow authorities (the Department of Information Technology and police) to stop citywide use of facial recognition AI during public gatherings, arguing it violated privacy (personal data laws) and free assembly rights. Their claims were dismissed – first by the Savelovsky Court in 2019, then by Tverskoy Court in 2020, which found the AI-enhanced CCTV system lawful and not infringing citizens’ rights. The courts noted that the city’s use of face recognition was justified for public safety and that the technology’s 65% accuracy meant it wasn’t a definitive personal identifier.

excerpt:
"	Por padrão, entende–se deepfake como imagens sintéticas que são criadas a partir de tecnologias de IA e aprendizado de máquina que permitem a reprodução de padrões de imagens que foram combinadas, fundidas e trocadas com uma aparente autenticidade.

As críticas políticas, ainda que duras e ácidas, ampliam o fluxo de informações, estimulam o debate sobre os pontos fracos dos possíveis competidores e de suas propostas e favorecem o controle social e a responsabilização dos representantes pelo resultado das ações praticadas durante o seu mandato.

A extensão da noção de propaganda antecipada negativa a qualquer manifestação prejudicial a possível pré–candidato por cidadãos comuns transformaria a Justiça Eleitoral na moderadora permanente das críticas políticas na internet.

Das postagens do representado não se extrai pedido de "não–voto", mas crítica política um tanto jocosa, abrangida por seu direito constitucional de liberdade de expressão e de manifestação do pensamento, dos quais se utiliza para tecer críticas à qualidade das ruas da cidade, bem como para enaltecer o seu atual trabalho de vereador pelo município.

A mera utilização de conversão de texto para voz (Text–to–Speech) não é suficiente para caracterizar o uso de deepfake ou para macular os vídeos como falsos, como se estivesse o representado a manipular e adulterar a verdade dos fatos, ou a simular uma voz famosa para angariar apoio eleitoral ou conferir mais credibilidade ao vídeo.

Recurso não–provido, em total consonância com o parecer ministerial. Sentença mantida na íntegra.
